¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	On the manner of cauterization in ailments of the lungs and cough.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When cough and lung ailment are from cold dampness, and the patient has no fever, nor consumption, and the ailment is old; then cauterize him with two cauteries above the fork in low, smooth, safe places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And with another cautery in the middle of the chest between the two nipples: and let the cautery be a tube according to the form which preceded.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish to cauterize with a point, using a cautery called "Punctum," whose form precedes in the piercing of ear pain; and let there be points from thirty points up to others like that.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with that which preceded, until he is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now let there be a cautery having three branches: according to this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Therefore, let it be eased with cauterization when you make with it once three cautery tools.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	On the manner of cauterization in a laceration, in dislocation of the humerus.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head is dislocated because of moisture and does not return to its place within an hour after being dislocated, until it becomes accustomed to returning, then it is dislocated again with a slight movement, which happens as we have already testified, then it is necessary to reduce the dislocation first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then the sick person is laid on their back, or on their healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then raise the skin which is in the inner Tilici towards the upper parts with your left hand fingers: and if the joint is dislocated inwards.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then having a cautery of fire with two handles.
Cuius forma est haec.	Its shape is this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates to the other side, and the figure of the cauterization will come with four cauteries.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And sometimes cauterization is performed with a cautery having three strands, therefore the figure of cauterization then becomes that of six cauteries: and the strands are according to the fineness of the thread.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the form of a cautery having three handles.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And sometimes one is added above this mode, wherefore there are eight cauteries.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then put upon the cautery crushed leeks with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make the weak adhere to tranquility, so that the limb may not be moved at any time until it is strengthened.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if dislocation is upwards, and rarely does that occur, then cauterize it above the shoulder with a cautery, or cauteries many, puncturing.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint is strengthened and moisture is removed, and the weak one is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	On the manner of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When cold and much moisture occur in the stomach until it is drawn from its composition, and catarrhs multiply to it, and constant modes of treatment are used, and it does not help: then it is necessary that the sick person be placed on his back, and extend his legs and hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauteries, one cautery under the ear of the chest the size of one finger with one cautery clamp, and two cauteries below on both sides of one cautery until a triangular figure of cauteries is formed.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And extend between the two so that they may not join, when they make pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be the quantity of two-thirds of the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the figure of cauteries be according to this form without addition: and if you wish to cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this form: and let the cautery which makes this cautery be one according to the shape of a circle according to this form.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And the stomach is cauterized by pricking it for him who fears this cautery; and it is, as signs on the stomach point according to the quantity which you wish with encaustrum; then cauterize it with a point cautery; then care for it with the cure which preceded until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	On the manner of cauterizing a cold abscess.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When there is pain in the liver from cold and humidity, or from thick wind, until it departs from its natural composition by superfluity, and the sick person is cured with what we have said, and does not improve: then it is necessary that the patient be laid on his back over his shoulder, and signs with a cauterization three times according to this figure, and this same quantity below the Epate inferiorly from the hypogastrium, where the arm of man reaches. And let there be a space between each cauterization according to the thickness of a finger: and let the cauterization be according to the length of the body straight: and do not press your hand with the cauterization too much.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the quantity that is burned be according to the thickness of the skin, the quantity of half of it not being added; and let the weak one stand on his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	If he is not standing, then let him lie down, who has already extended his legs and raised his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the shape of a cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And it is indeed possible for you, that you may cauterize these cautery wounds with a knife-cautery, when you have subtlety and prudence in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And guard yourself, that you do not proceed too far in cauterization, and the thickness of the whole skin is burned, wherefore the whole body is burned, and it comes to the intestines: because the skin there is thin, therefore know this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	On the manner of cauterizing abscesses of the liver.
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When an abscess occurs, and you wish to know if it is in the liver tissue or its covering: then if it is in the liver tissue, a painful ache invades the sick person, and heaviness without sharpness; and if it is in the covering of the liver, with pain there is extreme sharpness; and you see already that it has fatigued his physicians with treatment.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore, let the sick person lie upon his neck.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then the figure of the place of the abscess with a cautery: then the fire of the cautery which is similar to a ray.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with it one cautery, until the whole skin is burned, and it reaches the fascia, until all pus exits: then take care of its treatment of fistulas, until it heals.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And it is not right that this cautery be used unless one's study in the art of medicine is prolonged, and by whose hands these pains occur with experience many times; then indeed let him dare to perform this kind of operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	But to dismiss her with me is better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	On the method of cauterization in pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter XXXI.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said that a cautery with roots of asarum was applied to cold pleurisy in this way.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is, that you receive from the roots of dried and long birthwort, one root longer, which is found in it, and let it be like the thickness of a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse it in oil: and kindle it in fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with one cautery where it is between the continuation of the fork and the neck, and with two small cauteries under a slightly sloping guide to the part that is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And with two cauteries also in that which is between the fifth and sixth ribs sloping toward the rear a little: and another cautery in the middle of the chest, and another above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And with three cauteries from behind: one where it is between two spatulas: and two cauteries from the two sides of the chest, lower cautery which is between two spatulas.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And you ought not to press your hand with the cautery, indeed let it be in plain sight on the skin, smelling.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some ancients have said that there are people who use a cautery from iron similar to a rod: and they ignite it, and put it inside where it is between the ribs, until it reaches the abscess with it, and pus comes out: just as we said in the case of an abscess of the liver.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this perforation with a cautery there is fear, that either the weak one dies immediately or it happens in place a fistula, which has no healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	On the manner of cauterizing the spleen. Chapter XXXII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you treat the illness of the spleen, as we have said from the treatment in the division of illnesses, and your treatment is not effective, then cauterization in it is according to three ways, which are all right.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	Of which one is, to make three cauteries, or four lining according to the length of the spleen according to the figure of the cauteries of the Liver, whose figure preceded.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let the amount of cautery be the thickness of a finger, or slightly more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let the way of cautery be, which we said in the cautery of the liver, equally.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not press your hand with the cautery: and let the weak one lie on his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another method of cauterization is: to have a cautery with two handles, which we said in the chapter on dislocation of the shoulder: and elevate the skin which is over the spleen, where the elbow of the left arm reaches; and let your elevation be according to the width of the body, so that the cauteries fall along the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then insert two burning rods carefully until they penetrate the skin on the other side; then remove the cautery: therefore four cauteries are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with a cautery having three handles.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then care for the cautery after you let it discharge pus for many days: for it is more beneficial than all that preceded from healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	On the method of cauterization in dropsy.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	Cautery does not fall into dropsy except with proper incision.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you treat Hydropsy with the methods of treatment which we have said in the division, and the treatment does not help, then it is necessary that you cauterize it with four cauteries around the navel, and one cautery over the stomach, and another over the liver, and one over the spleen, and two cauteries behind the back between the vertebrae, and one directly on the chest, and another directly on the stomach: and let the quantity of the depth of the cautery be near the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then release the open cautery so that it may discharge pus for a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And do not remove the weak one from treatment after cauterization with him: for it is necessary that two intentions be joined to him: and he will hasten to himself healing with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The shape of the cautery used to cauterize the abdomen should be a clamp, according to what preceded; and the shape of that one used to cauterize the back should be an olive, according to what preceded its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	On the manner of cauterizing feet and legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When abscesses occur in the Hydropsy (a condition of fluid accumulation), and they are filled with yellow water: it is necessary to cauterize on the dorsum of the foot, which is between the auricular and annular areas: and raise your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it: then raise your hand: and do not repeat it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	The water will boil then, and let the cautery be according to this form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make on each of the two legs two cauteries in every leg, and let the cautery be made with the edge of the knife of the cautery: and let the cautery be made according to the length of the leg, one below the knee, and the other lower, about the middle of the leg: and on each hip two cauteries: and dismiss the open cautery without cure for a long time: so that something of water will be reduced from it: then care for it with the rest which we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	On the manner of cauterization in the solution of the abdomen.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXXV.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When there is a solution of the belly from cold and moisture until it weakens the retaining and digestive powers which are in the stomach and intestines: and it is cured with modes of cure, and it does not heal: and you see the infirm person enduring the cautery of exuberant virtue, then cauterize him with a great cautery above his stomach, according to what preceded in the cautery of the stomach with a circular cautery, and four cauteries around the navel fine, with a subtle cautery clauili: and a cautery above the alcatin above the alehosos large, or two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see abundant moistures, and the patient bearing it weakly, then cauterize it with a cautery over the comb, and with a cautery over all of the groin; and perhaps add two small cauteries near the large stomach.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	It is indeed a healing method whose benefit does not err.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	On the method of cauterizing hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter XXXVI.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are many old hemorrhoids in the anus, or one, and they are from thick humors, cold ones, or corrupt humidities, and they are cured with what we said in the division, and the cure does not help: then cauterize with three cauterizations above the lower vertebra of the back under the slightly triangular almeidati, and cauterization below the navel like two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is chilled, and his food is not digested, and you see his face suppurating, then cauterize him over the stomach with a large cautery, according to what preceded: and cauterize him over his spleen, and another over his spleen, with a clauili cautery: and release the open cautery after some time: then care for him until he heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	On the method of cauterizing the  artery after its section.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter XXXVII.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you cut the flesh, then apply the cautery of fire that is like a ray.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then introduce the burning instrument into the cut flesh; and with your last hand, until the cautery reaches the opening of the vein from which blood runs, do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If therefore many ulcers are present, then cauterize each one with a cautery according to what we have narrated.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then care for that, with what ointment it helps, until they are healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize him with a large cautery on linen, it is more ultimate in healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	On the manner of cauterizing a fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the sick man does not obey the incision and operation which we have narrated in its place, and is terrified by it, perhaps he heals with cauterization.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When therefore it happens to someone that he has a fistula, and it becomes old, pus runs out of it, and corrupt humors.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore it is fitting that you examine it with a fine probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then know the quantity of its depth with a probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then use cauteries of fire, which are like a ray.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then introduce yourself, ignited, into the fistula itself and the quantity into which the nail has entered.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat the cautery on it, until all those corrupted bodies are burned, once, or twice, or three times, according to the quantity of your necessity.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And guard yourself from burning the nerve if it is there, or the large vein: or if a fistula goes to the body of the bladder, or to the body of the intestine, then guard yourself from all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not do this unless there is a fistula in a fleshy place: and you consider that it is not penetrating.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then care for the place until it is healed.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	If, however, the place is sealed, and materials are cut away from it, and it remains so for a long time, then you shall know that it has been completely healed.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if they do not cut away the matter from it, then know that it is penetrating, or there is a rotten opening in its depth, or like one of those: whose recollection will come in its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	On the manner of cauterizing the kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When pain occurs in the kidneys from cold or from a great wind, and it is lessened because of this ailment of the weak, then it is necessary that you cauterize it above almethenem above the kidneys themselves, with a cautery over the whole kidney with a cautery clauili, whose preceding mention has occurred.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we shall cauterize it a second time within the flesh itself.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Therefore, there will be three lines.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore they will be more useful in the healing.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	On the mode of cauterizing the bladder.
Caput XL.	Chapter XL.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When weakness and softening occur in the bladder due to cold and humidity until it no longer retains weak urine, then cauterize its lower part above the bladder where the hairs of the comb begin, and one cautery from the right side of the pubis, and another from the left of it: and let the length of this cauterization be according to the quantity of a knuckle; and cauterize it with a lower back cautery, or two cauteries if it is needed by that: and let the cautery be closed as before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	On the method of cauterizing the Matrix.
Caput XLI.	Chapter XLIX.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When cold and moisture occur in the womb and it prevents impregnation, and her menses are corrupted, and their arrival is delayed, and pain occurs to her at their advent, then it is necessary that she be cauterized with three cauteries around the navel, as we said in the cauterization of the bladder, and cauterium on a cushion below the back, or two cauteries: and let the cautery be clauile.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	On the manner of cauterizing a wound in a dislocation.
Caput XLII.	Chapter XLII.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When the mucous humidities are poured out to the Anchae  and become the cause of its exit from its place: and the sign of this is that one leg is lengthened over the other, when they are compared side by side: and the place of dislocation is found empty in it.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore, it is necessary that the one who cauterizes the diseased part above the margin of its own cautery makes a similar circle: after you have marked with encaustic on the circumference of the margin, as it turns: and so that the itself falls in the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cautery be of the form that preceded in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If you do not have this cautery at hand, then cauterize it with three cauteries, with a large olive-wood cautery, and let the depth of the cautery be according to the quantity of the thickness of the whole skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	On the method of cauterizing in sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the hip joint, and the cause of it is cold and moisture: and the sick person is treated with what we have said in the division, and the treatment does not help, and it gets old: then it is necessary that you free the sick person from gross humors with fetid pills, or with artificial pills, and similar things.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize him.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the mode of cauterization in it is according to two modes: either cautery with medicines that burn, or cautery with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	Burning with fire is according to many ways.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of these is, that you cauterize on a piece of wax of the anus with three triangular cauteries, according to this form.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make a good depth for them, or bad.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And let there be a space which is between every cautery the thickness of a finger; and let the cautery be oiled.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	Sometimes a cauterization is done in the middle above the head of the hip bone.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Therefore there are four cauteries.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you wish to cauterize with a circle, whose form preceded in the cauterization of the dislocation of the hip, one: so that it be a circle containing the whole hip.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the thickness of the whole skin.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method of cautery for sciatica, when the pain adheres to the hip itself, and does not extend to the hip and leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If it extends as far as the hip and leg, then cauterize it with two cautery instruments above the hip, above the place where the sick person indicates, where there is pain, and with your cautery over the tail four finger widths to the left side a little: and let the cautery be a knife-shaped one.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be according to the depth of the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the patient says that the pain extends almost to the toes of the foot, then cauterize him there where he indicates with a cautery, point, three, or four, or more, if it is needed.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if he indicates pain being under the knee towards the leg, then cauterize it there with a one-bladed knife cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And beware in all your cauterizations that you do not come to the extreme with the cautery so as to burn nerves, or a great artery, and draw through it upon the infirm a bad evil, or contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	And I myself have seen one and another of those who cauterized above the tendo Achilles and continued in cauterization, and the leg became inflated until a tumor was formed on the foot, and the whole foot was perforated and corrupted; then there followed solution of the abdomen, and death after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If pain is in two parts at once, cauterize both according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men have said concerning the cauterization of the anus, whose cautery this is the mode.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a saw like this from iron, whose diameter is half a palm's breadth: and let it be at its opening according to the thickness of a finger's knuckle, or a little less: and inside that saw let there be a third saw.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And let there be space which is between every stitch the amount of a finger's joint: and let the stitches be open from two parts: and let their height be like a knuckle, or two knuckles: and make for them a handle from iron properly fitted in the stitches.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then it is set on fire until it glows red and throws off sparks; then it is placed upon the wax of the healthy side lying over the ailing side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Therefore, cauterize him with three round cauteries in one vice.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then dismiss him for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Afterwards apply plasters with butter and let the open wound be left for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says, about this type of cautery, O sons, we have used it little, because of the fear of its appearance: and therefore, because we have found few who await upon it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	Nevertheless, it is good for those who suffer from burns and find a place for it with them.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	The cautery however when with burning medicines is to make two samia having perforated armillas, into which descends the hinge of its door from brass or iron, the length of the wall:  in whose height there are two knots, or as themselves.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	Let there be a space between the two parts of the size of a finger's width, and let them be open below and above: and let them contain themselves against each other, according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place it upon the bed of the hip, the infirm lying on his sound side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand upon the pimple of the anus much.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between two circles hot water, which has been heated with fire a little, and hold it for the quantity of an hour's time: and let the sick person endure its biting and scorching, for he himself finds the biting as if from fire until the biting subsides.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then raise your hand with an instrument and wipe away the hot water from the whole wound with sweet water; then let it be left alone for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And place over this butter until the blackness of the burn is removed; and let it stand for several days, and pus will flow from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	It is indeed the last thing in healing.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments, until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extends to the hip or leg, make for him a splint in what contains water, according to how you made it even.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the way of hot water: and I have already written it in the treatise on the rectification of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkali and unquenched quicklime, each one half a part: grind both, and place them in a new pot, whose lower part is perforated with a small hole, according to the quantity that will enter it [the radius]: and place under the bottom of the pot another pot vitrified. And pour over the alkali and quicklime from sweet water, so that both are submerged by a finger: after which you compress them with your hand good compression: and let go the pot until the sharp water descends to the lower part of the vitrified pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then collect that whole water and pour it over another lime; and stir until it is renewed.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	For it will then be very sharp and strong, which is administered in many operations of medicine, and in cauterizing the remaining limbs.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	Because it performs the operation of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And of medicines are those with which they cauterize wounds, just as with the testicles, and honey of cashew nuts, and lime mixed with soap, so that both are mixed together.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galen indeed narrating reported, of a certain man from ancient times, the cure by which he was cured of pain in the hip and sciatic vein: and magnified it to be very great.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said that it did not need other treatment, and because it was healed from one application, until it returned, because perhaps he himself entered the bath brought in, and came out of it already healthy.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is, as it is taken from the green seitaragi: and if it is not found green, take dry, fresh; and it is prepared much with a little fat, and put upon the place, where there is pain, or leg, or in the hip; and it should be left on for three hours or until the patient feels a burning sensation.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then introduce him into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When therefore the body becomes damp, introduce it into the socket.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For pain departs, and healing takes place.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And know that no one should use a cautery with these medicines, unless after evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides said that when the sciatic vein is cauterized with goat dung, it helps; and the cautery is made in this way.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Take wool, and soak it in old oil, and place it over the deep place which is between the thumb of the foot, and between the big toe, and it is closer to the big toe.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take dry goat dung, and set it aflame until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place him upon wool, and let him be, until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Then again.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Therefore, do not cease doing this until you feel sensation through the mediation up to the depth and rest of pain.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cauterization is called cautery of the Cow.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	On cauterizing back pain.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter XLIV.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	Sometimes pain occurs in the back from many causes, either from a fall, or a blow, or the evacuation of superfluities, and similar things, from the infusion of cold and humid matter: and cauterization does not apply except in this single case, which is caused by the infusion of cold matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	Therefore, after evacuating the sick person with foul-smelling pills and similar ones, three lines should be made on the back where the pain is, according to the width of the patient's loin, after signs have been marked with encaustic paint on every line five cauteries, or more according to the amount that comes from the endurance of the patient's strength; and cauterization should be made with a cauterizer.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cautery instruments, with a medial clamp cautery, according to this form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	On the mode of cauterization in an incision of gibbosity.
Caput XLV.	Chapter XLVI.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This ailment often happens to young children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its beginning in children is: that which happens above him constriction in breathing at elevation, and movement: and you find in the last vertebra of the back and its knots, which has already begun to protrude above the other vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you see that, and wish to make that, then cauterize it with a cautery which is circular according to this form.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And let him take the cautery over every part of the spine equally: and if you wish cauterize around the spine with a cautery point two lines, or three: and let the points be close to each other.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then care for the place until it heals with that which we said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And beware, lest you administer cautery in the hump that arises from a nerve spasm.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	On the manner of cauterization in gout and joint pains.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVI.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When pains in the joints are from cold moisture that flows to any limb of the body, and when they happen in the feet, it is customary for physicians to call it Podagra properly.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When therefore gout is treated because of cold causes with methods of treatment, and the pains are not removed, then a cautery removes them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is, that you cauterize him after evacuation at the juncture of the feet, with many cauteries: and let the cautery be Olive oil.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its form.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you need to make points on the face of the foot, then make them with a cautery.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	If the pains ascend to the knees or other joints, and this often happens, then cauterize the entire knee with three or four cauterizations from all sides, with the same cautery as Claudius.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If you need more of this burning with a cautery, then burn it again with a cautery.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not submerge your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be about the thickness of only the skin.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If however pains ascend to the knees and back: then administer what we have said from cautery in its chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If the pains are only in the hands, then points are pricked around the circumference of the focus, as two lines revolve.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If pain remains in the fingers, then prick them above every node and on the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If pains should rise after days to the shoulders or elbows, then cauterize both from every part.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not evacuate the infirm from good regimen, from receiving medicine.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	If a good regimen is followed and the phlegm is evacuated, it will heal with the help of God and this cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	On the manner of cauterizing in ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groin and the intestine or testicle descends, and this is beginning to be near, then it is necessary for you to order the patient to abstain from eating on his day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let him use gentle laxatives, so that stool descends from his belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then he should sit between your hands upon his back: and bid him hold his breath until it comes out, or appears, the tumor, or intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce it with your fingers, and mark with encaustic under the fracture on the breastbone, with a sign whose extremity is similar to the half of a circle toward the upper body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then the fire cautery, whose shape this is, until it becomes white and throws sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine, or bowel, to its cavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then the assistant places his hand over the place so that the intestine does not come out: and you have already opened between the legs of the sick person, and placed a cloth under him, and one servant on his legs, and another on his chest who holds his hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then lay the cauterizer upon the very mark, with your hand holding the cautery straight.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it until you get to the bone with it; or repeat this with another instrument, if you have not reached the bone with it at first until you do.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And carefully observe from the exit of the intestine at the hour of your cauterization, lest you burn it, and there may come through it upon the weak either death, or great evil.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not succeed with a cauterizing tool in closing the bone, your operation is of no use.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cautery for infants be fine, according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care with the rest of the ointment, until it heals.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the infirm be lying on his back for forty days, until the wound is sealed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary that you put nourishment in him according to the length of time of his healing, so that he may soften his belly, so that it does not go out of the intestine at defecation and excretion.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wishes to rise after forty days, then administer a properly made bandage and have him hold it for forty days again.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And he should abstain from labor and repletion of food and drink, and loud voices.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when this regimen is used, it heals with complete healing.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I will say the treatment of ruptures with incisions in its chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When ruptures occur in the rest of the abdomen, and they are beginning, and you wish that they not be added to, then cauterize the rupture with a round cautery according to its size: and let that which is burned from then on be as one third of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then care for it as we have said: and nothing more be added.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And now some first said that a rupture should be cauterized with a triangular cautery, according to this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	After it is marked with wax and a line which is across the width on the upper side of the rupture is placed, and another line below.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with a closed cauterizer.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But a cautery is first easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	On the manner of cauterization in pains caused by a fall, or percussion.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When pain occurs in certain limbs from an accident or blow, and that pain persists for a long time, and does not help with treatment with medicines: then it is necessary that it be cauterized with a pointed cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let the cautery of every limb be a cautery according to its size, and its suitability, and its weakness, and its strength, and the location of the torsion, and the pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If therefore it is cured by the first cautery, it is well.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not, then repeat cauterization over it.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	Because it is customary for these pains to shift from one limb to another that is near it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore it is necessary that you follow them with a cautery until the sick person heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	On the way to cauterize in leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	Leprosy is sometimes helped by cautery with great benefit.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the kind of leprosy, which is caused by the rotting of phlegm and melancholy: therefore when you wish to cauterize it, consider this.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If therefore leprosy is incurable, and you have treated it with what we said in the division, and it has not descended nor stood; and you fear over the infirm that corruption will encompass the whole complexion of him: then cauterize him on the head with five cauteries: one in the middle of the head known, and a second below toward the forehead at the end of the hairs, and two above the two horns, and one behind on the nape of the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And lastly your hand with the cautery briefly, until it makes a slight impression in the bone, and the layers of skin are separated from it, so that the expiration of thick vapor from it may be alleviated, and cauterize also the spleen with the cautery, as above.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	If leprosy has already spread over the infirm person, and appears manifestly: then it is necessary that you cauterize with these cauteries which we have said in the beginning, and a cautery on the extremity of the nose, and two cauteries on the two maxillas, and two cauteries on the vertebrae of the neck, and six on the vertebrae of the back, and one large one on the bones near the root of the tail and one above it, in the very middle: and two on the buttocks; namely, on every buttock with one, and two on the knees; one on every knee, and two on the shoulders, and two on the forearms, and two on the tendernesses of his chest: and cauterize him on every joint, from the joints of the fingers of his hands, and feet: and cauterize on every heel of his feet, and wrist of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And be careful of the nerves which are above the heel bone, so that you do not burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And sometimes it is cauterized with a cautery above the bone of the breastbone, and another above the bone of the stomach, and another above the ribs.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And know that the more you add cauterium, it is more helpful and more effective.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that the infirm does not find pain in cauterization as they who are healthy find it, because the body of him is already numbed.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it is necessary that the cauteries be of size and shape according to limbs and joints; as was said previously from the kinds of instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care is taken with a cautery made from herb flour and honey, and the rest of the treatment, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	On the manner of cauterization under anesthesia.
Caput L.	Chapter L.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When a certain limb is numbed, and it is treated with medicines, and oils, and plasters, and does not heal, then cauterize that numbed limb with cauteries, according to what the size of the limb deserves, or its smallness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your cautery be inserted into the thickness of the skin a little.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And sometimes it is cauterized to a certain numbness, which happens to the hand and foot, in the shoulder blades of the back at the exit of the nerves that move that limb: and the numbness is removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	Truly, he should not presume over it, unless he is wise in the anatomy of the limbs, and the exit of the moving nerves from the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	On the method of cauterizing in Albaras.
Caput LI.	Chapter LI.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albucasis says this and does not contribute something from the minds of medicine: then cauterize above it with a deep cauterization for a short time, according to the quantity of the thickness of the skin, until the white is removed, and its color is changed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with flour of herb, and lentils with rose oil, and arnoglossae leaves, and dove blood, and swallow blood: let each be one part: mix all these things, and spread them on cloth, and adhere to the place until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	On the method of cauterizing in cancer.
Caput LII.	Chapter LII.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When cancer is beginning, and you wish to stop it, then cauterize it with a circular cautery in a circle around it, as it revolves.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	Wise men have said that it should be cauterized with the last cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	It does not seem right to me because I fear that it would ulcerate, and I have already seen this happen several times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is more correct that it be cauterized around it with a circle, as we have said; or with many cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	On the method of cauterizing in Adubelati.
Caput LIII.	Chapter LIII.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has an abscess and it delays in ripening, either because of the excess matter causing it, or because of the age of the patient, when he is old with little blood, or because of time, and one wishes to hasten the ripening of the abscess, then cauterize around it with small cauteries punctating many times.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then let it go.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For itself it will hasten with ripening.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If you wish to make a perforation of it with a cautery, then ignite the cautery, which has this form.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of the Abulati, until it penetrates the skin; and let the cautery be from what follows weak, so that the course may be eased with pure.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then care for him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	On the manner of cauterizing in a bad gnawing wound.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIII.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	Consumption is nothing but corruption in a limb that walks, and it eats into it; just as fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If therefore you see a lesion in a place that will bear cautery with fire, then apply much cautery with fire, small and large clamps, according to what is suitable for the place in which the lesion is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from every part until you eradicate the entire corruption, and let nothing of it remain at all.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then dismiss him for three days, and put over the cauterized places sulfur rubbed with oil, until all the scabs are eradicated, and all corruption is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then care for him with ointments that generate flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If therefore you see that after three days flesh is born with a healthy birth, in which there is no corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then apply a cautery again upon that which remains from the places corrupted.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And it is sometimes treated with a sharp medicine when it corrodes.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	For it rises in place of cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	Nevertheless, cauterization with fire is more rapid healing; and indeed I have already said cauterization of it with sharp medicine in division: therefore accept it there when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	On the method of cauterizing in nails and warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter LVII.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	Often this ailment happens in the lower parts of the feet: and it is a thick, filtered thing, which hurts the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And indeed a cautery is used in these two ways: cautery with fire, and cautery with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	As much as it is with fire, so the cautery should be like a concave feather of an eagle's wing, made from iron according to the quantity which contains the nail on all sides and have a subtle margin.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then place it burning upon a stake.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then roll the hand with a cautery around the nail, until the cautery reaches the depth of the nail; and let it go for three days, until it begins to discharge pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then place a plaster on it with willow bark and pounded salt, and leave the plaster over it at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	For it will be eradicated from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with a healing ointment until it is healed.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they are not converted, and often happen on the surface of the body, especially in the hands and feet: then administer cauterium to them with hot water: and it is, that you take a tube from copper, or iron, or from the quill of a vulture: and lay it upon a nail, or an althelul.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then pour a small quantity of hot water into the tube: hold your hand and roll it with the compression of your hand for a short time so that the edge of the tube is imprinted on the root of the nail, and the hot water finds its way to the deep, to the root of the nail: and let the patient wait for a short time over the application of the hot water for one hour.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then let it go, for a claw is eradicated with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Thus do with them one after another, until you come upon all who are in the body from among them.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then care for them after they are removed, with that which generates flesh from ointment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	On the manner of cauterizing in tremor.
Caput LVI.	Chapter LXVI.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When someone has a tremor from cold in the nerve, or from quartan fever, or otherwise: then it is necessary that you cauterize it with four cauteries, or five on the vertebrae of the back, and between every vertebra with cautery, and on his chest with cautery, and on his stomach with cautery.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	For tremor rests with a clyster of oil and health hastens in cold sickness.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	On the manner of cauterizing Albathir.
Caput LVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	Sometimes foul matter, that is, pustules, are expelled from the body of Albathir, which are made from corrupted thick substances.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	Therefore it is necessary at first when they appear, that the head of every pustule be cauterized with a fine cautery of myrtle wood, whose end has been set on fire with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of long birthwort.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a lentil-shaped cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And sometimes, when the boils are cauterized at the beginning of their discharge, in this way: and they do not increase; and the superfluousness is broken by them, and it heals from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	Nevertheless, it ought to be done after evacuation with bloodletting.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	On the manner of cauterizing a flow of blood from an artery in a wound.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter LVIII.
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Often there is a flow of blood from the artery which has been cut at a wound, whether it happens externally, or at the incision of an abscess, or cauterization of a limb, and the like; and it becomes difficult to stop it.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.
