When this happens to someone, then hasten with your hand to the opening of the artery, and place your index finger upon it: and press it very hard until the blood is stopped under your finger, and nothing comes out from it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then place in the fire a small oil-burning cautery, and many more; and blow over them until they are well ignited.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take from them one, or a little, or much, according to the wound and the place where the artery is broken, and place the cautery over the vein itself, after which you remove your finger quickly: and hold the cautery until the blood is cut off.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	If it is expelled with the finger from the opening of the artery and the burning cautery is extinguished, then take another cautery more quickly, prepared from cauteries which are in fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Therefore, do not cease doing it with one after another until the blood is cut off.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And beware, lest you burn the nerve that is there, and an other evil befall the sick person.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from an artery, then it is not possible to cut it off except with one of four ways.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a cautery, as we said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction when it is not extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is drawn out, the extremities of it contract, and blood is cut off.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it may be tied with a strong ligature of thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or let medicines of property be placed upon it, which are for cutting blood and tie it with a ligature in a proper manner.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	He who administers the cutting away of it with a bandage, and constriction with a cloth, or the placing of burning things, and similar things, does not completely apply it, except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If it happens to someone and there is no present physician, nor medicine: then begin with the position of the index finger over the opening of the vein of himself, as we have narrated, and constriction of it greatly, until the blood is stopped from the upper part of the wound, and over the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger should not be moved, and it is to be always moistened from above with cold water of vehement coldness until the blood congeals and thickens, and it is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile let him consider in it what is needed from cautery, or from medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of the First Part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On Incisions, Puncture, and Bloodletting in Wounds, and Similar Conditions.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have said in the first chapter all about illness in which it is fitting to combine cautery with fire and burning medicine, and its opportunities, its causes, and its instruments, and the forms of cauteries.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed heads there from the crown to the foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I shall proceed in this chapter along the same path so that he who seeks may find what he is looking for.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin this, it is necessary that you learn, O sons, that in this chapter there is the same thing as in the first chapter on cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And for this reason, it is necessary that caution be taken with greater diligence, because in the operation which is in this chapter, very often evacuation occurs with blood, by which life stands at risk during the opening of a vein, or incision over an abscess, or opening of a fistula, or healing of a wound, or extraction of an arrow, or incision over a stone, and similar things: from all of which there accompanies trembling, and fear, and in many of them death occurs.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you, let not that which is in doubt fall upon you, for sometimes men with ways of sickness come to you with ways of this art.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	From these things there is one who becomes angry with his sickness, and for him death is light; because of the vehemence he finds from his infirmity and length of his malice.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And with pain is fear that means death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And of these there is one who gives his tibiae and nourishes you with it, hoping for health, and his sickness is pernicious.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore, you ought not to consent to him who comes to you from those, whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	Let your caution be greater than your greed and avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume anything from that, unless after certain knowledge which verifies with you that which to which it has arrived a praiseworthy succession.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And attend to the care of all your sick, with prognosis and indication of that which is fitting for their health.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	In this therefore is your help above the acquiring of fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, sons, with his understanding, and may he not take away from you guidance and inspiration; for that is in his hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I indeed have ordered this Chapter by dividing it into sections, according to what preceded in the chapter on cautery, from the neck to the feet; so that the seeking which you want from it and in which you need it might be eased.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	On the cure of water that collects in the heads of children.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this infirmity often happens to boys at birth or when a midwife squeezes the head of the boy without lightness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And whenever it happens also from a hidden cause which is unknown.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I indeed did not see this ailment in others than in children: and to every one whom of them I saw it hastened death: therefore it seemed good to me to omit the operation in it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I myself saw among them a boy whose head was filled with water, and his head grew larger each day until he could no longer sit on himself because of the size of his head; and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture indeed either gathers between the skin and bone: or it gathers under the bone over the fascia.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation on this, if there is moisture between the skin and bone, and the abscess is small, then it is necessary that you make a fissure in the middle of the head, one in width: and let the length of the fissure be as two knots, until the moisture runs.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the shape of a spatula.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the humidity is more increased, and the abscess is greater, then place those two incisions, according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is under the bone, and its sign is that you see the seams of the head open from every part: and water is depressed when you press it with your hand to the interior, and it does not hide from you: then you must make three fissures in the middle of the head, according to this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after incision, remove the entire humidity.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then bind the fissures with cloths and wool.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then stitch it above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the ligament, and take care of the wound with a bandage, and ointment.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not let go of tightening the head with equality.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the sick with every dry food of little moisture, until the limb is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another way of cutting is, that you should consider where the magnitude of the abscess appears, and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	Because sometimes it is in the back of the head, or on the forehead, or on the right, or on the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore ascend with the incision where the abscess and water filling appear to you: and split it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, that you do not cut the artery, and that there does not occur a flow of blood, and that the sick person does not die from that flow with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	On the incisions of arteries which are behind the ears.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When a certain person has catarrh to the eyes or chest and it gets old and medicine does not help; then the last cure for this is an incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore, when you wish to cut them, let the sick man shave his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the place with a rough cloth so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then let the weak man tie his neck with any of his cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the vein pulses.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the places of both are places which are behind the ears depressed: and rarely is it concealed, except in certain men.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark both with a cauterizer, and cut both with a spatula, each side being sharpened to the bone, with the incision reaching the bone, so that it is across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert a spatula under the artery, and cut it upward with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be as two joined fingers.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when a vein is cut, blood flows out with a pulsatile emission, which leaps to the interior with frequent leaps.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If however the artery does not appear to the sense, then it is necessary that measurements be taken from the ear to determine the quantity of space three fingers' width.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then signs with an encasing and fine up to the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which ought to be emitted from blood is VI ounces and perhaps you emit more, or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All of it according to the quantity which appears to you from the strength of the patient and the filling of his artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if something remains at the bone from the incision, then cut it so that a hot abscess does not occur; then bind the wound with linens made of flax cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	On the extraction of arteries that are in the temples.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When a person has an old headache or acute catarrh due to acrimonious humors and heat in the temples, or an old, violent sore and similar ones: and it is treated with modes of medical cure, and it does not benefit: then we have experimented in these ailments extraction of the arteries from the temples, or cauterization of them, as we have narrated.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the way of operating in the extraction of them is, that the unhealthy hairs which are on the temples, should be shaved and applied to the apparent artery in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	For indeed it is shown to you from its pulse, and rarely is it concealed except in a few men, or in the vehemence of cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it is concealed from you, then the weak person should bind his head with any cloth of his own; then rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or place steam with hot water until an appearance becomes manifest to you.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the spatula which I formed a little while ago.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then scrape away the skin with it until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then throw into it a hook and draw it upwards until you have drawn it out of the wound and made it come out from the tunics which are beneath it on every side.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If however the artery is slender, then wind it with the point of a hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from that part according to the amount by which the extremities are lengthened, and contract them, so that there is no flow of blood.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not struck and if it is not cut off, blood does not rise fully.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then evacuate from blood six ounces, up to three.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large, then it must be ligated in two places with a double, strong thread of silk, or with alhuhod cords, so that it does not quickly go to putrefaction before the wound has consolidated, and blood flow occurs.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the superfluous flesh that is between two ligaments.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this at that hour, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery up to the bone, with a knife-shaped cautery: until its extremities are cut and it will stand in place of the same work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is better to work, unless if the sick person has a fever, or an heated constitution.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Because cautery is one of those things that help to end moisture.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better healing.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the removal of arteries that the place be filled with old burnt cotton: and put upon it wool pads made centrally.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the dissolving it is treated with dry medicines which make flesh grow, and with poultices until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If, while you are operating, a flow of blood from an artery occurs, then hasten to cut it off with a cautery, or to fill the place with zea. And grasp your hand, until the blood is stopped.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If none of those things are present for you, then place your finger on the location until the blood clots.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And embrocate the place with water of violent cold until the sharpness subsides, and tighten it as is necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And because it is lighter and easier to extract the artery, it is that you cauterize the vein with this cautery having two blades: and let the sharpness of the two blades be similar to an almond.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	Nevertheless they are of much less sharpness than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	Because if they are sharp, like two knives, one should apply cold to both; and they do not cut flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Therefore, when there is a slight thickness in them, heat of fire is applied to them, and flesh is quickly cut away; therefore, this work is better than all works, lighter and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space between the two knives be the quantity of the thickness of a finger, after you have marked the two places with encaustic wax: and lay both burning ones gently until they reach the bone, and cut the vein in two places; so that it may be lengthened from its extremities.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For these are not thoroughly solidified with this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the shape of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	On the treatment of acute and persistent tearing from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When there are constant tears, and there is a flow of them from the veins that are above the skull externally: and it does not help anything with medicines in their cure, and you see the face of the sick already red, and he feels a wandering on his forehead, like the walking of ants: and his eyes are exhausted, humid, so that even the hairs of them have been corroded with corrosion: and his eyelids have been heated from the sharpness of the tears: then the ancients devised in their cure by this operation, and they named this cure, With a Sword.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is, as you instruct the sick person to remove the hairs that are on their forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then cut three equidistant incisions on the forehead according to the length of the forehead: and let the length of the incision be about two fingers' width, and one incision be equidistant from the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second according to the length a little from the movement of the arms, and the third from the other part: and beware of the incision of the arteries which are on the two sides: and extend your hand from the continuation of the two jaws, and let the space of all incisions be the quantity of three fingers joined: and let there be prepared for you a piece of sponge, or many dry cloths, with which you will dry the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then introduce a spatula with two pointed ends, whose following shape is.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision which is on the side of the temple, up to the second incision; and scrape with it all the skin, which is between the two incisions, with the sifac, which is over the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then make it also from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then remove this spatula and insert into the first incision again another instrument, which is called a sharp chisel, blunt on one side, sharp on the other.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place the sharp side of it against the attached flesh with the skin, and the blunt side towards the bone; and drive it until it reaches the median fissure; and cut with it all the vessels which descend from the head to the eyes; except that the incision should continue up to what appears from the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then make it in the middle fissure until another fissure.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after an equal quantity of blood has run out, squeeze the places from clots of congealed blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then put in every wound of flesh from cooked entrails, and put on them small pellets soaked in wine, and oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see that a hot abscess does not occur.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day, dissolve the ligament and administer a large infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment of bdellium and the rest with which wounds are cured, until it is healed.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	On the treatment of acute and chronic tears and catarrh of the eyes from internal parts of the head.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When someone suffers from acute, sharp, persistent catarrh: and you see their eyes weakened, small, and their appearance already debilitated: and the eyelids are ulcerated, and hairs fall out of them, and there is a sharp, painful pain deep in the head, followed by sneezing: then take from these occurrences that these materials and catarrh do not come unless from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And better treatment for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is, as you prescribe, for the sick man to shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then cut in that fissure one in the middle of the forehead, or another a little across its width, and begin with the fissure from the left temple to the right temple: and let the incision be up to the bone: and lengthen your hand from the temples, which move when chewing: until when the bone is revealed: and you shall dry all the blood with sponges.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the fissure with a boiled sheep's gut, or with lint made from linen.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then bind from above with pledgets: and soak the pledgets with wine and oil so that a hot abscess may not occur.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you have loosened it, and see that the hot abscess is already diminishing: then it is necessary for you to cover the bone until flesh begins to grow in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then care for it with a drying regimen which causes flesh to be born; such as if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony; and prepare a plaster from these, and administer it to the nativity of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	On the care of that which falls into the ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Everything that falls into the ear is one of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or something like a stone, such as iron and glass: or it is from a plant, such as beans and chickpeas: or it is a fluid thing, such as water, vinegar, and things like these: or something animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When therefore a stone falls into the ear, or a kind of stone from those which do not grow in the ear, expose the ear to the sun: if therefore you see the stone, then distill into the ear something from beaten oil, or sesame.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer the extraction of it, and make him sneeze with the condiment, and plug his nostrils at the entrance of sneezing, after which you place around the ear pieces of cloth, or wool, and extend the ear upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	It often happens with this treatment.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If it does not come out, then administer its extraction with Gesti, that is, Pizigarolis thin ones: whose form is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If therefore he comes out with a gasp, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer its extraction with a subtle hooked probe of little duplication.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If therefore it does not come out through that [opening], then make a tube of metal, and introduce the end of the tube into the ear hole deeply, and put wax which is around the circumference of the tube with softened lard, so that there be no way for the wind except through the tube; then draw out with your own breath forcefully.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For it often occurs with that which we have narrated.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	If this method does not work: then take from helkalimbat, or from visco, that is, prepared gluten, with which birds are caught, a small amount: and place it at the end of the radius after you have wrapped upon it a cotum placed centrally: then introduce it into the ear opening easily, after you have dried the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If therefore it does not come out with all that we have narrated, then hasten to cut (it), before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the mode of incision is that a phlebotomist should first cut the infirm on the head: and draw out of him blood according to the measure of his virtue.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the sick person sit between your hands, and turn his ear upward, and find a small fissure at the root of the ear in the depressed place among the fat: and let the fissure be of a lunar shape until you reach the stone; then remove it with what instruments are possible to you.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then suture the fissure at your time with speed, and care for it until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If a thing falling into the ear is from one of the grains that grow and swell, then administer its extraction.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it does not obey you at the exit, then take a thin, subtle spatula, according to this form.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with that the removal of that kind from the grains, which fall into the ear, and do not do this when you think that grain is already moistened by the vapor of the ear, until you place it in a piece of many: then extract them with hooks, or with a fine bristle, or with suction, as we have said, for its extraction will be eased.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	In the water that enters the ear, it is necessary for the sick person to use sneezing with condensation first of all: and already filled his ear with a little cooked leather: and he is lying on that ear, in which is the water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If therefore it goes out through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones, according to the length of the finger, thin, soft, and heat them with fire a little, and let the sick person insert one of these into the hole of his ear: and he shall jump on one foot from that side, and strike with another stone upon the stone which is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Therefore, do not cease to do this with stone and stone until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now water goes out, so that you may take from papyrus, or from rush one, and insert one end of it into the ear: and set the other end on fire until it burns most of it.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then insert another hook and do this many times until all the water comes out; and draw it out with a tube according to what was said before, in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In the extraction of an animal entering it, if it is small in size, like a flea, and the like, take care of it as I said in the division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is a large body that appears to the sense: then administer its extraction with pliers and hooks: and the matter of it is easier than all things that are held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	In the extraction of a worm generated in the ear, when you have treated it with what we said in the division and in the treatment of distillations, and your treatment does not help; then it is necessary that you look at the ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If therefore something appears there from worms, then remove it with forceps or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	If nothing appears there, then take a tube, whose form is this, narrow below, wide above: and insert the slender end into the ear according to the amount that the sick person can tolerate it; then suck with it with strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this many times until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If they do not obey you to the exit, then wrap the tip of the cannula with wax, as I said on the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If they do not emerge with what we have said: then administer distillations which the ancients have already tested in the destruction of worms: and you will find it in the treatise on distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your pouring of oil and medicines into the ear be with this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see, make it of silver or copper, narrower below, with a small hole, wider above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Therefore, let what is in the concavity of the tube be made of properly shaped copper.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a reed, and wrap cotton at its end with a decent wrapping: then throw oil or juice or what you wish of these medicines into a cannula: and let it be in the ear: then introduce the reed with cotton from above, and squeeze it with your hand with moderate compression, until oil is driven into the cavity of the hearing, and the sick person feels it inside. And that which is poured into the ear, should already have been warmed with fire for a little while: and beware lest what is distilled into it be very cold: for medicines do not tolerate this.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	On the treatment of an accident of ear wax buildup.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes infants emerge from the wombs of their mothers unperforated.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it also happens to some people that there is an obstruction in the ear canal from a wound, or flesh born in it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this application sometimes occurs deep within the ear canal, which is not seen by sight; and sometimes it happens to the outer part of the ear canal a little, and it is seen by sight.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Therefore that which happens deep within the ear, and which sight does not comprehend, is in many dispositions difficult to heal.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in that which follows the use, you ought to place the ear of the sick person in the sun, and look into it: then if you see a seeming hairiness, open it with a fine spatula, whose form is this which follows, let its extremity be in which there is a small breadth, of which part is sharp: and the rest of the spatula be gentle on two sides: so that it does not harm the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If therefore an ear discharge is born of flesh in the ear canal; then hold it with a fine hook, and cut it with ease of violence until the whole flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If a pain is deep within the ear, then take a fine, soft rod and heat it with a little fire; then put it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If therefore you sense obstruction with that which the sick man finds with heaviness of hearing, try to open it with facility; and beware, lest you wound the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then place licorice in the ear according to the amount of the opening's size which you have covered with Egyptian ointment; do this for several days, until you are certain about the wound's consolidation.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take licorice and infuse it in rose water, and pulverize over it ground saffron, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see an ear already suppurating, then it is necessary that you extract the pus, and allow it with another cloth, which is wrapped in a poultice that has been made with rose oil, until the abscess becomes seated warm: then take care of it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If, however, there occurs a flow of blood, then immerse a sponge or cloths in cold water and place them over the ear; and use the rest of the treatment which cuts off the flow of blood as has been prescribed in the treatise on distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	On the Treatment of Styes of the Eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	Injuries of the eyelid which occur in the eye, sometimes are humid, and sometimes are dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore, it is necessary that you hold them with forceps: or with a hook, and cut them with a spatula from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place over the places a mixture of zegi rubbed.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a subtle lentil cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And it is better to cauterize them after incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For many times they return when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots burn and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	On the treatment of granula of the eyelids of the eye.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Many times something happens in the eyelids that is similar to a grain of sand in its hardness and thickness, and because of this it is called a granuloma: and it is an aggregation of thick moisture in the upper eyelid, and the lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation therefore is, that you should consider then, if there is a granuloma proceeding in it, which appears from the eyelid, and move to every part, and its matter is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Therefore find a fissure over it lengthwise.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape it from every part with ease until it weeps.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend it with a hook, and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	If it is not prepared for you, its cutting, except after you have penetrated the eyelid with a slight incision, then it will harm the sick person in some way.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If the fissure is large: then gather it together with suture: and care for it, until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, no evil will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For the ointment restores it and makes flesh of it.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the fold is large and sloping towards the inner surface of the ear, then turn the eyelid back, and suspend the fold with a hook: except that you need to make an incision, and press it from every part.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	If the eyelid is lengthened through an incision, it does not harm in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the cutting with salt water: and take care of the place with that which is applied, until it heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the treatment of injuries to the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter X.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	A tumor is fat that is generated in the tunic of the upper eyelid: and it happens very much to boys: and it weighs down their eyes, and they get catarrh in the mornings, and they cannot look at the light of the sun because tears flow to them, and therefore you see them lie down on their faces always, and on those they sleep, and their eyelids are under the eyebrows wet, which has already been covered by inflation: and the tumor indeed is visible to the eye, and when you press the place with your fingers, you feel the fat between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the mode of operation is that he places his head in your bosom.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth and prepare a groove in it, and make a circle from that groove according to the amount which contains Asirnath from every part.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place him upon it, and press with your fingers from every part, so that Axirnath may be gathered in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of that moisture with a sharp instrument make incisions lengthwise, and let not the incision be greater than that which is made in phlebotomy in depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or it is necessary that you cut through the whole skin until you reach Axirnath, for in many arrangements Axirnath proceeds from the fissure according to the form of white, fatty wood.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Therefore, extract it with a cloth which you have saturated between your fingers to the outside: and you will turn your hand to the right and left, until it is scattered: and beware, lest you add it into the fissure, so that you do not reach the eye with the spatula, and wound it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	If, however, Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the fissure, you add a little into the fissure with ease, until Axirnath proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract it, as we said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then submerge cloths in vinegar and water, and place them over the spot, and bind it with bandages.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are some men who rub salt and place it in the hollow of the fissure so that it melts what remains of its moisture.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for the same, until it is healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If a hot abscess occurs in a place, then treat it with soothing plasters until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	On the ways of a cataract of the eye, that is, when the eyelid softens the eye, so that it becomes wrinkled as it should not.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When hairs grow on the eyelids besides the course of the natural hairs, and they age: then these harm the eye, and cause ways of disease to happen, such as frequent tearing, and softening of the eyelids, and clouding, until that becomes a cause for the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And a cataract of the eye is treated according to four modes.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or with fire using cauterization.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with acute medicine, according to what was previously stated in the chapter on cautery.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or it is cured with an incision and suture.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or through tubes, as I shall say.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary that you place the head of the sick person in your bosom.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If therefore it turns, it is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: introduce a needle into it, where the thread is from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle penetrate with the thread from above, and let it be near the hairs themselves, that is, near the edge of the eyelid, in which hairs are born: and draw the thread upwards with the eyelid, and turn it with a stick.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find in the inner part of the eyelid under the added hairs with a spatula, cutting from the greater lacrimal gland to the lesser lacrimal gland.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then remove the thread, and place under the eyelid a small piece of cooked linen or cloth: then mark over the eyelid with encaustic wax, so that it is like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that the figure be made according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid, because this varies in different people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	Of these there is one who needs to be incised from the eyelid an amount that is large according to the quantity which is softened from the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then when you have marked two lines with your spatula, begin from the larger lacrimal gland to the smaller one, and let there be a fissure near the natural hairs, as thick as the thickness of the radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert a hook into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape away the whole area.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then, with a needle and fine wool thread, gather together the two lips of the wound. Wipe away the blood, and make the excess threads adhere to the two eyebrows, with some sticky things, if you wish to do this; and if not, don't worry about it.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then dismiss the suture and thread up to three days, or four: afterwards care for it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without suture, and care for it so that it dries and tightens.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid should be raised during the sealing and closing of a wound; but it will be better later.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This way of healing a wound was taught by the ancients, Albucasis.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	But there is anxiety about the sick person, and it is from a good operation, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another method is in Ataxmir also: and it is, as signs on the eyelid make a figure like the shape of a myrtle leaf, as we have narrated.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then lift the eyelid with three separate or combined hooks, according to the following form, then cut away the excess with small scissors, according to this form, with equality of incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	If it is not possible for you to hold a hook and it is not equal: then take an awl in which there is a thread, and introduce it into the middle of the figure: and introduce another thread near the larger lacrimal, and the second thread near the smaller lacrimal: and gather together between your fingers the threads with equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then lift your hand with an equal elevation: and lift the skin over which the incision is made, as we have narrated.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound with a suture: and care for it until it is healed.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If however a boil should occur at your incision or fissure, treat that boil with cauteries and similar things, from sedative ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens to the eyelid, that its hairs turn.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore, you should use what we have said about incisions; but sewing both sides is more artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	On the treatment of a toothache with dogs.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is, that you convert the eyelid, and cut the fissure which is within, according to what I have told you.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then with the art make two pipes or two slender rods: whose length shall be according to the length of the eyelid, and their width shall be less than the width of a spatula: and you have already incised at the extremities of both sides where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then gather both together with subtlety over that which is superfluous from the eyelid of the eye, and tighten two reeds from both parts with strong constriction, and release it after a few days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For if the skin is tightly bound it will die and blacken and putrify until it falls away of itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If therefore it delays, then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When therefore it is consolidated, the eyelid is elevated; and hairs do not prick.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the shape of two tubes, which you will make according to this figure, and quantity in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	On the elevation of piercing hairs in the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation consists in taking a fine needle and introducing into it a fine silk thread gently.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then gather the extremities of it, and knots both sides with a subtle knot: and let the length of the threads be one palm.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then take another fine thread of silk and place it beneath the first in a short space, and knot its ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then the patient puts his head in your bosom, and let it be near the sun as the operation is declared; because it is a subtle or minute operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert a point with an alembic into the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate quickly into the eyelid until you withdraw it from above the natural hair.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then draw the arrow up beyond the point of piercing: and introduce the arrow into that point of piercing: if it is one, or two, or three, no more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then draw your hand with it until the hair comes out with its root along with the natural hair on the eyelid.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If it is drawn out and the hair does not come out with it, draw the alinxotati down to the lower part, with the thread that you have composed in it, until the alinxotati comes out of the upper opening, and you see it with the eye: then pull on the alinxotati and the thread, and extract both, and close the eye. And release it closed for two days or three, until the hair adheres to its place, and flesh is born above it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then either associate with it a longer hair from natural hairs, and elevate it with it; or let it be, until it lengthens after a space, and then elevate it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	On the treatment of a pterygium which occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this happens to the eye, it is called Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this is either natural or accidental, according to Al-Zahrawi.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Therefore, an accident occurs from the consolidation of a wound, or section, or cautery, and similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of operation on this is, that you find that consolidation and that you separate its lips, and you place between them a ligature made of linen, and you bind it, until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And it is not right that you should use things which dry and constrict in the treatment of this [wound]; for if you do so, Alxatrati returns worse than it was; rather, use things that soften it, such as hay: and embroca with water in which althea has been cooked, flax seed: and unguentum dyaquilon, which has been liquefied with some oil; and envelop with this licorice, and care for it with this.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And your treasure of healing is that you try with every skill that it not be solidified, according to the form which it was at first.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation which we have said, is nothing but a certain rectification of Alcatiraet, so that it does not return to the form of the place according to what it was entirely.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	Concerning the treatment of a pterygium which occurs in the lower eyelid and is a wrinkle or contraction upward to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This is the Alxatrati which is performed below, it is truly named Alxatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	It is natural and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And an accidental wound is made from a cut, or fissure, or cautery, and those similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way of operation in this is, that you take a needle, in which there is a doubled thread, and dye it in meat, and make it penetrate from the left lacrimal duct to the right lacrimal duct, until the thread comes to both extremities of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh upward with a knife, and cut it with a broad spatula.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If therefore the shape of the eyelid returns as it should, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take a probe and put it in the fissure, and turn it with it the eyelid: and find two fissures on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two fissures be from two angles of the incision, until they meet and an angle is made of them; until when they are gathered together this figure is made, and it is the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh by the amount, which is its acute side below, from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then gather the separated parts; sew them together with a woolen thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what we have said, about softening medicines and poultices, until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if a laceration occurs from a cut, and suture, or cautery: then it is necessary that you find the fissure flat under the hairs of the eyelid, also according to what preceded.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with a linctus, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the summary of the discourse on the care of an Alxatrati, when it is above or below, is that the operation should be carried out according to how it is prepared from the form of an Alxatrati.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For indeed there are many varieties in form: and a wise artificer prepares the instrument with whatever mode is possible to him, until he makes the figure return to its natural form, or near it, and himself also the infirm according to what is fitting for him from the operation and instruments in many arrangements.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	On the adhesion of the eyelid of the eye with the conjunctiva, or cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this consolidation happens to many people, so that the upper eyelid adheres to the white of the eye and prevents it from performing its natural functions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore, you ought to insert the extremity of the radius under the eyelid and raise it upward; or extend it with a hook: then cut the adhesion with a spatula, which should not be sharp at the point of the spatula, but rather blunt for a little while: so that the sick person may not be troubled during the operation, and the spatula be removed, and injure the eye with its sharpness: and let your incision be as if you were scraping off that adhesion with ease, until when the eyelid returns to its natural form, and the adhesion is healed entirely.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour salt water into the eye, and wash it with water; or distill into it from a sieve made, from linen dissolved with water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and eye with a linen cloth: and place over the eye wool soaked in alum mixed with white of egg: and after the third day use sieve, and with solids, until it heals.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	On the incision of the nail and the prominence of the flesh of tears.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that a nail is according to two modes.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is nervy and is similar to a hard, fine sieve.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not a nerve, similar to frozen water of white color: which when it touches iron, or you try to seize it with a hook, it breaks off, and the hook does not fasten in it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both kinds do not begin unless from the larger lacrimal duct, until it goes gradually, until it covers what is necessary, and prevents light and the movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the mode of operation in its incision is: that the sick person should place his head in your bosom.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes, and lift up the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then collect a thread with a small hook and extend it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle and insert into it a thread made of horse hair, ox hair, or camel hair: and let the thread be strong, and double the end of the needle for a short distance, and fix it in the middle of the hoof: and pierce it with the needle, and bind the hoof with the thread, and extend it upwards: and scarify with a hair the side of the hoof which follows the pupil, and if you join it with hair until its very end.
