Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If this instrument is not present to you, then take a tube, and put cork on the end of it: so that the bone of the sick person does not burn: because cork prevents steam from burning the bone: and this is good cure with health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On the extraction of thorns, and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVII.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Often a piece of bone adheres in the throat, or a fish spine, or something else.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore, you ought to remove what is apparent from them which falls under the sight, after pressing the tongue with an instrument at the sun, and it is declared to you what is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And that which does not appear to you and is hidden in the throat, it is necessary for you to make vomit weak before food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps indeed it will emerge the annexed thing through vomit.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Let the sick person swallow a piece of barley bread, or the root of lettuce, or swallow a mouthful of dry bread: or take a piece of dried marine sponge, soft, and tie it with a thread, then swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When therefore it arrives at the place where the spines or bones are, and is drawn out, then it comes forth.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If therefore it does not come out with what we said: then use an instrument of lead according to this form.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than the radius a little, and at its end let there be a curvature, so that it may enter its gullet with ease; and let it also have its head elevated upward.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And let him beware of touching his epiglottis, so that it does not happen to him that he coughs and drives in with it his mouth, or a pin, or introduce himself the physician with his hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	Truly it is better if the sick person himself inserts it, because of his knowledge of the location of the thing attached: and he should push downwards, or draw his hand with the instrument upwards, the whole thing according to the quantity which is prepared for him, until it emerges.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the removal of the leech.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When a leech is treated with what I said in the division on treatment with medicines, and it does not help, then consider in the throat of the sick person in front of the sun, or in the sun after pressing his tongue with the instrument that I told you about.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your sight falls upon a leech, remove it with a small hook, or with fine tweezers.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If it is not possible with them: then take a concave tube and insert it into the throat of the sick person up to almost the gullet; then insert into the cavity of the tube a burning iron with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this many times: and let the sick person abstain from water all day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a mouthful of cold water, and open his mouth in it: and put his mouth into it, and do not swallow anything from it: and move the water every hour with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For when the leech feels water, it immediately falls.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If it does not come out as we have narrated, then fumigate the sick person with cumin, or with asa with the instrument which I have narrated in the fumigation of the vulva.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times, because it itself will fall.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in fumigation is that you take a pot, in which are live plums with fire: and let the pot be covered with a lid, in the middle of which there is a hole: and let the extremity of the instrument be placed in that hole.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then throw the fumigation and let the sick person put his mouth at the end of the tube, and close his mouth so that the fumigation does not go out, until you know that the fumigation has already reached the bloodsucker.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech will immediately fall off.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not fall, then repeat fumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the weak endure thirst, and eat salt and other things, and not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is therefore necessary that he should depart with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which bloodsucker is extracted from the throat, when it falls upon itself.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to forceps, as you see: except that it has this curvature which goes into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its extremity is similar to the beak of a bird called a stork, in which there is the roughness of a file: when it grasps something, it does not let go of it at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	On the opening of abscesses, and their incision, and care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter XL.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of boils, many different ways, according to how they are remembered, namely one, and one in this book: and they are diverse in their piercing, and their cutting from two ways.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	Of which one is of a kind of abscesses within itself, and that which it comprehends from humidities.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second mode is because of the places, in which it happens from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Because an abscess occurring on the head is different from an abscess occurring in the anus: and an abscess occurring in a fleshy place is different from an abscess occurring in the joints: and to each of these their own judgment by operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And from abscesses there are some which ought not to be pierced unless after the ripening of the healing in them, and the completion of it: and from these there are some which ought to be pierced while they are raw, and do not ripen according to the completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Like abscesses that are near the joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Because an abscess when it happens near a joint and is prolonged to be so, until it rots what is around it, perhaps the ligaments or nerves of that joint are corrupted: therefore it is a proper cause of the contraction of that limb.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Either it is an abscess at a principal member: because if you delay its piercing until it matures, it will harm either him or through that principal member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	If it is near the anus, pierce it unripe: and it is not necessary to pierce a fresh abscess, not completely digested, unless it is near the anus so that it does not putrefy deep, and lengthens to the interior of the anus, and becomes a fistula, or becomes at its end what does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary that you know the hour of perforation of an abscess, which has matured according to its completion: and this is found in the sedation of pain, the recession of fever, and the diminution of redness, and pulsation, and the sharpness of the head of the abscess: and other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And it is necessary that you make the same perforation in the lower part of the abscess and of the more prominent eminence: and let the perforation be sharp in length of the body, if the abscesses are in the parts of the hands and feet, and places of the limbs, and tendons, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all equal places, where there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those things which are reflected, go with a perforation according to that limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When an abscess is in fleshy places, it is better to let its discharge out, until its digestion is confirmed, as we said according to the completion.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you pierce it before that place, the course of the pus from it is prolonged, and there is much dirt and filth, and perhaps the lips of it and its depth will harden.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And certain abscesses are pierced according to the width of the body as needed; or according to what the limb needs.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you administer in small abscesses a small perforation, and in large abscesses a wide perforation; or many sections according to the similarity of the size of the abscess.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And they are from abscesses, in which it is necessary that the skin be concaved: and it should be cut when already made like a cloth, and made at the end, which is already dead: such as happens to many, so that it may ulcerate, and buboes.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And among these are those that are cut with a three-angled incision.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And of these there is one which occurs like the figure of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like an inguinal abscess.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And among these there are those in which a round incision is administered, and a lunar incision: and similar to these incisions.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	For that which has no head, such as superficially soft boils, it is necessary to perforate it with a superficial or only flat puncture.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary, when the abscess is large and has already collected much pus, and you pierce it, that you do not hasten and extract all the pus in that hour: rather, extract a part of it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then apply a poultice to the abscess until the next day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then remove something from the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to the gradation until it comes out: especially if the man is weak in strength, or a pregnant woman, or a small child, or an old man decrepit, for indeed the animal spirit is much dissipated from the animal with the discharge of phlegm: and perhaps the weak one dies, and you do not perceive it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore, this chapter should be read with great caution.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have pierced your abscess, it is necessary that you cleanse the wound and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If therefore is a wound of little inflammation, or is a flat incision, then administer a poultice from linen, or old cloth.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if there is a large abscess and there are many fissures of perforation, it is then necessary that you insert into each fissure licorice until they come to meet each other.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if in an abscess you have cut away a part of the skin, or in its circumference have hollowed it out: then it is necessary that you fill it with sheep's wool, or as when a bandage is applied, or be powdered with flax lint without moisture: and bind it until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then throw it out, and care for it with that which is necessary from ointment, until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If blood flow occurs during your operation, then administer cold water and vinegar after a cloth has been soaked in them: and place it over the place of blood flow many times.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If the flow of blood persisted, then it is necessary that you administer a regimen and treatment and powders, which I have recounted in many places in this book of mine, and from the division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If it is wintertime, and the site of the abscess is near many nerves, then you should pour hot pills mixed with wine and oil onto the place.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it be in summer, and the places are fleshy: then it is necessary that you place poultices soaked in water, and oil, or him with wine and oil, and the whole cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day, as we have said, then it is necessary that you loosen the abscess, and cleanse it, and administer to its cure what is fitting for it, until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore what is necessary from the knowledge of the treatment of abscesses universally.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the method of distinction, I have already said about every kind of abscess, how the way to its cure is taken chapter by chapter individually.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	On the incision of boils that occur in the scalp.
Caput XLI.	Chapter XLIX.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small abscesses occur in the skin of the head, and they are of the kind of boils, which contain pouches, which are like little bags of a hen's udder.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their kinds are many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Some of them are fatty; and some contain moisture similar to mud; and some contain moisture similar to gruel and porridge; and the like, and some are hard and stony.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the sectioning of all and their extraction there is no fear, as long as it does not oppose an artery at their sectioning.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in their cutting is, that you may experience it with an instrument, whose form comes after these, which is named Intromissum, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	If it contains moisture, then dry it out with a cutting along its length, superficially: according to this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with a cut from line b to line g. When the moisture has been evacuated, then scrape out the cyst which contains that moisture, and do not let anything come out of it completely.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	Many times indeed it returns, if anything remains of it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the cotton in Egyptian ointment, if it is present: and if not, in water and salt: and fill the wound with it, and leave it until the next day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For it will also corrode that which remains of the cyst.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat upon the same wound with the Egyptian second, and third, and if it does not suit you with that, until you are confident that nothing will remain from the cyst, then take care of the wound with ointment, until it is healed.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If it contains a fleshy node, then cut it according to this form, with the incision having the shape of a cross: and throw hooks between the lips of the incision, and scrape it from every part: and strive your strength in extracting the tunic that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If an artery does opposition for you, then do that which I will tell you after this.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And similarly do in an abscess, if it is stony, from the cutting and the same care, according to what we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the section over a stony abscess is easier; because it has little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are some of these abscesses that are in the head in certain men, with which there is no moisture at all deep within.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is because I cut into an abscess on the head of an old woman, and I found an abscess like a solid and hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken; and if anyone struck it with something throwing, it would wound him.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other abscesses occurring in the head, besides these namely abscesses that occur in the heads of children, and at the roots of the ears, the section of all of them should be a superficial section.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or place the perforation of them always from the lower part of them, so that the course of healing may be eased to the lower parts.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care should be taken with that which is suitable for healing them.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	On cutting the windpipe constrictions in the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter XLII.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	Very often these abscesses occur in the neck, and under the arm pits, and in the groin: and sometimes they occur in the rest of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And above those which happen to them in the neck, there are one and many: and they are generated from each other: and every Strophula is from them within its own tunic, just as it is in knots and abscesses of the head, as we have narrated.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of these Strophulars.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And of these there are stones: and of these there are those which contain humors: and of these there are malignant ones, which do not obey cure.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In that one therefore which you see of good disposition in touch, whose manifest color is close to the skin, and moves to every part, and is not attached with nerves of the neck, nor with guidegi, nor with artery, nor is deep: it is necessary that you cut it with a superficial incision from the upper part to the lower part of the body from line b. to line g., and scrape it from every part: and extend two lips of the skin with a hook, or with many hooks, if you need it, as we said in abscesses of the head, and extract it gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is a precaution that one should not hit a vein or a nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the spatula not be too sharp: so that it not add your hand with the incision, or trouble the sick person, and cut what is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If you cut a vein or an artery, and this prevents you from operating, then place in the wound crushed zege or some powders that stop blood flow, and tightly bind the wound, and leave it until the sharpness of the abscess subsides and the wound softens: or until it begins to want to putrefy.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is cut off with the tunic.  Therefore go back to your operation until you have finished it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then inquire with your index finger if anything remains of the small strophuli; therefore cut them and cleanse them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If a large vein is in the root of the strangulation: then it is necessary that you do not cut that strangulation from its root: rather it is necessary that you tie it with double strong thread, and let it fall by itself without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with cotton wool which you have already submerged in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then care for it.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the entire strophula is cut, then it is necessary to join the two lips of the wound together; and its own, immediately after you see that there is no longer any superfluity.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If, however, you see that there remains an excess because of the size of the Strophula, then it is necessary that you extend yourself to cut its root and remove it: and administer the suture which we said.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And what contains moisture from the strophules, perforate it with a superficial perforation: so that the place of its maturity appears to you: and place the perforation below where follows the lower part of the body, as we said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	After the perforation, administer a poultice with ointment and similar things so that it will corrode what remains of the corruption until when you see the wound already cleansed; then care for it with an ointment that generates flesh until it is healed.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the cutting away of the epiglottis due to an abscess within the throat.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients said that this incision was made in the epiglottis, and I did not see anyone in our land who had done it; and this is the writing of their words.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	When someone has a strangulation, it is necessary to make a section of the epiglottis: because if this is not done, no help comes because all the veins and lungs are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have a hot abscess in the mouth, or throat, or at both tonsils, when there is no pain in the canal, it is necessary to use a section of the epiglottis to avoid destruction which occurs from pre-inflammation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore when we want to cut the epiglottis, under three or four circles of the epiglottis, it is necessary with a small incision across, in that which is between two circles by the amount, that the section be in the fascia and not in cartilage: and this place is convenient for the section because it is devoid of flesh, and blood vessels are far from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the surgeon is timid, then he ought to extend the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he cuts the skin until he comes to the canal: if he sees anything from them (the vessels of blood), he evacuates it.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he cuts the siphon which we have recounted: and it is signified above the incision of the channel from the phlegm that issues from it, with that which is broken and the cutting off of the voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And leave the open wound for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When therefore it is removed at the hour when cataract is feared, collect together the two lips of the wound of skin, and sew itself alone without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer medicines that cause flesh to grow, until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Says Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The summary of this discourse which we have narrated is not an exposition, unless when they see that some of these abscesses has already opened the throat of the sick person: and the sick person has been raised up above death, and wants to be intersected by his breath: they go to cut the Epiglottis, so that the sick person may breathe over the place of the wound with some breathing, and may be saved from death: and for this reason they ordered to let the open wound until the evil of illness is finished, and it is its malice in three days, and as itself: then therefore they ordered to sew the wound, and care for it until it heals.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I saw with my own eyes was that one handmaid took a knife and put it into her throat and cut a part of the windpipe with it.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to treat him, and I found him moaning, as is the moan of a dead man.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I therefore examined the wound, and found blood which had flowed out of the wound a little.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	Therefore I was troubled that she had not cut off the vein nor guided it, and wind was going out of the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	Therefore, I took care of his wound and cared for him until it was healed; and nothing happened to the maidservant except a hoarse voice; and she returned after days to better condition.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore I say: that in the cutting of the epiglottis there is no fear.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On the incision of a hiatal hernia.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter XLIV.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This abscess called a hernia of the throat is a large abscess, according to the color of the body: and it occurs much in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it is according to two modes: either indeed it is natural; or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly, it is not natural talent.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	Accidental is according to two modes: one of which is like lumps of fat.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And another way is similar to a boil that arises from the tying of an artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in this there is fear, and it ought not to be presumed against it with a sword, unless in that which is small; and you prove it, and investigate it with the insertion.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If therefore you find a similar knot, plump and not suspended with any veins: then cut it, as knots are cut: and remove it with what it contains from the cyst, if it is in a cyst: and if not, then examine the whole of it.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place as much as is necessary until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	On incision over types of swellings.
Caput XLV.	Chapter XLIV.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of knots, and I have already said all their kinds in the division: and it is necessary that I tell here the difference between a Knot, and an Fistula: when there is doubt-making.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say therefore, that when the heat, and fever, and violent pains shall be settled until the boiling of superfluity is calmed, and putrefaction is complete: then indeed the fever and heat will rest.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When a node there is no heat, nor fever, nor pain, and it contains them in a bag called sifachin, which is proper to them, and is according to the color of the body: and its beginning is like a lentil, and it becomes like a batecha, and greater and lesser.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are according to two kinds: either fatty or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of humidity are many, according to what I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore, when you come to the treatment of a Node, you must examine it and inquire about it first with the instrument called Intromissum, according to what its form will be in the chapter that is after this.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the manner of investigating abscesses, and all nodules is, that you take this instrument and insert it into the moister place which you find in the abscess: and you revolve your fingers with it gradually until you know that the instrument has already penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then your last hand according to the measure of the size of the abscess.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then remove what was introduced and consider what comes out in its trail.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore a running humidity exits, whatever the color: then dry it with a superficial incision, according to what I said in the rest of abscesses.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if moisture does not issue from the track of introduction, then know that it is fatty: therefore make a dry incision over it in the form of a cross, according to this shape, as I have taught you; and suspend it with hooks, and scrape the skin from every part with ease; and guard the cyst if you can above it, so that you may extract it sound with the Node.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If, however, the bladder bursts during the operation, and it is not possible to remove it whole, since this often happens, then remove it piece by piece until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	If there remains something little, or much, from it, a Knot returns according to the greatest amount.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If it overcomes you, and there remains a little from it, then fill the wound at its completion with some sharp corrosive powders: and tighten the wound, and place above it what sits abscesses hot, and care for it with the rest of the cure until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If therefore it is a large knot, then cut two lips of it, and care for it with that which becomes flesh.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If the vein is against you, pulsating or not pulsating, then hasten, and fill the place with crushed zeige, and release it strict for two days, or three, until the wound putrefies, and the boiling of blood rests: then return to cutting that which remains from the Node.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	On instruments for cutting and piercing the mouth.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVI.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	Of these there are forms of instruments introduced, and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	Of these there is a great one, and of these there is a medium one, and of these there is a small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let iron probes of square extremities be made, centered, so that they hasten entry into an abscess.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of Experiences, and not, that is to say, piercing: and one of them is named beris, that is, piercing: and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	Of these there are great, and medium, and small.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	It is necessary that these abscesses and openings and fistula are investigated through what is between them from the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are made round, smooth, and blunt, like large needles which they use to stitch the wounds with, from brass, or copper, or iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the better ones are made from citron.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And experience is also made with black lead, which are suitable for testing fistulas, the concavity of which is such that they are reflected with their gentleness when reflected with those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And there are again three kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Because some are long, some medium, and some short, according to the quantity of the width and constriction of the fistula.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The shape of hooks, and there are many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	Because they are simple, that is, those which have one care; and there are three kinds as you see, Great, Medium, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And of these are blind pouches: and they are of three kinds.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And of these there are hooks having two curves, and they are of three kinds: and of these there are hooks having three curves, and they are of three kinds: and all these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of scalpels, with which knots and abscesses are cut and scraped; and they are of three kinds: because there is a large one, a medium one, and a small one.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	The extremities that are cut are sharp, and the other extremities are not sharp; and they are not placed like this, except that aid may be given to them in the scraping of nodules out of fear of incision of a vein, or nerve; and that the weak man may heal by them, and find for a short time tranquility from burning as he finds in the scraping of an abscess.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are called Magda and they are of three kinds.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of metal, and are similar to a still, with which alcohol is made: and at the wide end there is a small point hidden, Spatula; and through it it runs to the interior, and to the exterior when you wish, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The shape of a wound concealed between the fingers at the site of an abscess perforation; these are not felt by the sick, and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	Wounds of the winds with which the flow of blood is severed; and they are of three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They are made from copper or citron, round, of slight length, as you see: and let them be fine.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of Winds be with you both large and small, so that you may cut off blood with speed when necessary, and then when medicine is not present to you.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, do not use them for cutting blood in every part of the body, and do not use them except in fleshy places: such as the groin of the leg, and the hip, and the armpit, and the nipples, and the abdomen, and the inguinal region, and the like, from fleshy, moist incisions.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes instruments are made from these similar to the peelings of figs, according to their shape; with which blood is cut when it flows from the site of phlebotomy, or at the incision of a vein, or artery: and sometimes they are made round according to this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the care of the breasts of men which are like the breasts of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of some men become swollen at the time of sleep (that is, when they begin to dream) until they resemble a woman's breasts; and they remain festering with pus.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever avoids this, it is necessary that he cut above the nipples with a lunar incision, according to this form from line, b, to line, g. Then scrape away all the fat.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Afterward fill the wound with medicinal ointment.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound with a suture, and take care of it until it is healed.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If however the nipple inclines to the lower part and softens because of its size, as happens to women: then it is necessary that two incisions similar in figure to a lunary be found on its two upper sides, each one containing the other at the limits of both, until there is a greater line containing the lesser, according to this form from line, b, to line, g. Afterward scrape the skin which is between the two lips and remove the fat, and administer what we have said about sutures and powders, which is necessary for healing, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If, however, you are not able to make the incision as needed because of the patient's distress or because of bleeding, then it is necessary that you fill the wound with a paste submerged in corrosive ointment and let it sit until it corrodes what remains of the flesh.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for him until he heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	On the incision of an abscess that occurs under the nipple.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses that occur under the nipple are of a kind of hard struma, which contains cysts, and from these there are those that contain moisture.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	What therefore are those which contain humors, it is necessary that they be cut with a lunar section, according to this form, from line b. to line g. For when all that is in the abscess of blood is evacuated, then fill it with old ointment, and dismiss it until the next day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the clot is removed, and it is treated with a suitable ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the abscess is of the kind of Strangles nodules, then cut over it as we have said in the section on Strangles, equally.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If, however, the wound extends in this way that it emits pus, then administer to it a cautery, according to what we said previously.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	On the incision of an abscess that occurs because of an artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an Artery is ruptured and the skin above it is closed, many times abscesses happen from there; and similarly, with Veins, abscesses and swelling happen as well.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that an abscess and inflammation are due to the Artery and Vein are: because when an abscess is due to the artery, it is long, gathered deep in the body: and when you press the abscess with your fingers, you feel as if there were a creaking sound.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is for the vein is round upon the visible body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And a section above this abscess is an error, and especially that which is under the armpits, and groin, and neck, and in many places of the body: and it is very great.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore it is necessary that its care be carried out with iron, and what also from them exists in the extremities, or in the head, it is necessary that it be carried out.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore, regarding that which is from them [the wounds] by inflation of the orifice of the Artery, find in skin a cut in length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the incision with hooks, afterwards the Artery: and free it from the tunics until it is revealed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert the needle under it and make it penetrate to the other side, and tighten the artery with a double thread in two places, according to what I taught you in extracting the two arteries that are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then pierce the place which is between two ligaments with a lancet, until all the blood that is in it comes out and the abscess is dissolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer a cure that generates pus until the ligaments fall away; afterward care for it with ointments suitable to it, until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If it is an abscess due to the incision of a vein, then you must hold with your hand as much as possible from the abscess with skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce a needle under the place which you have held with your hand, and make it penetrate: and let there be in it a thread double, until you draw it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie the ligature with the abscess itself, according to what I told you about the ligation of the vein, from two parts with two extremities of thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If you fear that the extracted thread may be left behind, then introduce another needle with a different thread beneath the whole abscess at the incision; press and tighten your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry out the abscess in its middle, until when it discharges what is in it; then cut away the excess of skin, and release what is bound from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put upon it the little bit which you have submerged in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then administer treatment with liniments and ointments until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	On an abscess that happens from a twisting of the nerves.
Caput L.	Head L.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an abscess occurs in arteries and veins, so it also occurs in nerves; which occurs in them from a blow, or from excessive labor, and similar things: and it most often occurs in those places of the helpers, or heel bone, and in every place where joints move: and it is a serious abscess.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color is similar to the rest of the body, and it is found in many arrangements without pain: and when it is squeezed with vehemence, it feels in it weak like a stupor.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not an abscess gathered deep within the body, rather it is under the skin, and it moves to every part, and it does not go forward or ahead, nor backward to the back parts.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore, what is found of these things in joints, it ought not to be invaded with iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	For perhaps contraction will happen.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	In that which is in the head, or on the forehead, cut the skin with a sharp instrument.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If therefore is a small abscess, then hold it with forceps and cut it from the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a hook, and scrape it; then remove it, and gather the wound together with suture: and take care of it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	On the incision of an abscess that occurs in the abdomen.
Caput LI.	Chapter LI.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	Sometimes certain people get growths in their bellies and other parts of their bodies, which are called Fungalia, because of their similarity to mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Whose root is subtle, and their head is coarse, and their lips are reversed.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And there are some of them which are small: and there are some of them which are greatly magnified.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I myself have seen a man, and in his belly there were two growths, which were more like fungi than other things: there was no difference between them, white, small roots, and their lips were reversed, and they were found, and humidity flowed from them always.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	Therefore, I cut them, and I found in one about X and VIII ounces and in the other about VI ounces. And the operation in the incision of them is, that you consider then, if the patient is humid, and the color is white, moist, fine root: then cut it with a wide spatula, and let there be cauteries in fire present to you.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For often much blood is expelled during its section: therefore if you are overcome by blood, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see someone weak and fearful of the incision with iron, then take a leaden thread properly made, and bind it with it to the athulus: whose manner is what we have said, and release him for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add lead to the constriction.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Therefore, do not cease to tighten the lead until it is imprinted in the lil, until it is severed and falls by itself without labor.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If however the root is thick, then there is some fear and anxiety in its incision, especially since it is in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	Nevertheless it is possible, that you cut in half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then take care of the wound until it is healed.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And be careful not to cut into that which is dark in color, with few senses, and foul appearance; for it is a cancerous abscess: and I shall come back with a remembrance of Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the treatment of umbilical prolapse.
Caput LII.	Chapter LII.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	A prominence of the navel occurs from many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from fissures which are above the belly: and it exits from this either the large intestine, or the small intestine, according to what happens in other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Either from blood flowing from a Vein, or from an Artery, according to what has been said before.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or compressed by a tight bandage.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If it is due to a fissure and the discharge of pus: then the color of the abscess is similar to the color of the body: and it is soft, without pain: and it appears in various locations.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to the extrusion of the intestine, then its location is, with that which we have narrated, of greater diversity.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When therefore you press it with your fingers, it disappears; then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound with it; and it becomes much magnified at the entrance of the bath, and causes labor.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If it is due to moisture, it is soft, then it is not concealed when you press it with your hand, nor is there constriction, nor addition.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is due to blood, then with these signs the abscess appears black on the skin.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If it is due to flesh born: then it is a serious, large, hard abscess, and it sets according to the quantity of one.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If it is because of windiness, then its touch is gentle.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation on that one is, when you consider if the prominence of the navel is due to blood from the Artery or Vein, or windiness; then it is necessary for you to prohibit its cure.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in that there is fear and trembling, as I have taught you in the chapter, in which I said abscesses because of the artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the prominence of the umbilicus is due to the intestine or a tumor, then you ought to instruct the sick person to hold his breath and stand upright extended.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with a plaster around the whole umbilicus.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then command him to lie on his back between your hands.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then with a spatula wide around the umbilicus on the place which you marked with encrusting.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Afterwards extend the middle of the abscess to the upper part, with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind him around with strong thread, or with a silk cord, firm binding: and let the knot of the ligament be secure.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle of the abscess extended above the ligament.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you find it already captured by the ligament: then extract the alien body and introduce your index finger into it, and drive the intestine to the interior of the belly: and if you find a tumor, then take it with a hook, and cut away its superfluity.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If, however, the artery or vein is opposite you, then wind around it much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	Take two needles, and insert into them two strong threads: and insert two needles into the circle that you made around the abscess in the form of a cross, so that they penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then bind the abscess in four places over the needle: and if you wish, remove the needle, and let go of the place, until the extended flesh rots: and it falls by itself: or cut into it when it becomes subtle and rots.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with what is necessary from ointment until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If a protrusion of the navel is from flesh or moisture then it is necessary to concave the abscess as we have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And you will draw out blood, or moisture, which you find in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then care for it with that which solidifies the place.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	On the treatment of cancer.
Caput LIII.	Chapter fifty-three.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have said in the division of the types of cancer, and how is the way to cure it with medicines: and beware of it when curing it with iron, so that it does not ulcerate: and we have said about cancer generated in the womb, and caution in its treatment.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that sometimes cancer is in a place where it is possible to eradicate it, such as cancer that is in the breast or in the hip, and similar places, from limbs located to remove the whole of it, especially when it is beginning small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When however it is old and large, it ought not to be approached.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I was not able to heal anyone from it; nor did I see another before me who had come to that.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation on it, when it is located as we said, is, as before, and to purge the sick person from black bile several times.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then if you find the lancet with a manifest filling.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the weak with preparation, in which it will be spoken with the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then project into the cancer hooks that are suitable for it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Afterwards hollow it out from every part with the skin, according to examination, until nothing remains of its roots: and let blood flow, and do not cut it quickly, moreover express the places, and wipe away the gross blood all with your hand, or with whatever instrument is possible there.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If, however, a thick flow of blood occurs from the incision of an artery or vein: then cauterize the vein until the blood is cut off.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	On the treatment of dropsy.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIII.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	Now we recount in the division of kinds of dropsy, and how the gathering of water is made: and the signs of every kind, and its cure with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is cured with iron is only a kind of ascites alone; and it does not approach with iron the species of tympanitis; nor the species of hydrops entirely; for that is mortal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already treated this kind of hydrops tympanitis with medicines, and your treatment did not help, then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	If weakness has already come upon the sick person, or if there is another illness besides dropsy: such as if he has a cough, or a flux of the belly, and the like: then beware that you do not treat him with iron: for there is fear of this.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	If you see a patient with excessive vigor and there is no illness except for dropsy alone: and he is not a child, nor an old man; then the mode of operation in him is that you elevate the patient standing between your hands, and let your assistant press his belly with his hand, driving the water to the lower part of the breastbone.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a spathe prickly, according to this form.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	Let it be two parts acute, long, and the acute end like a spatula.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	Nevertheless, there should be something of brevity gradually, so that you do not pass through it with it at the time of the operation to the intestine, and wound it.
Deinde considera.	Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	If the formation of dropsy is from a part of the intestines, then it is necessary to lengthen with a cut from the navel three finger widths, down to the direct below the breastbone.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	If however the generation of hydropy is because of the sickness of the liver, then let your section be on your left from the navel three fingers.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.
