Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	If the old woman does not obey evacuation, then cleanse the sick person with a clyster containing a small amount of biting substance, so that it may wash what is in the anus and obey the exit quickly when the sick person expels it.
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	If, however, they are external to the anus, then their affair is light, easy: and it is as you capture them with your nail, or you capture them with a hook, and cut them.
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with that which we have said, until they are healed.
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And if one shuns cutting with a knife, then it is necessary that you administer suture of them according to this manner.
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take a thread wrapped and insert it into the needle.
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then draw the athil upwards, and make it pierce with a needle at its root on the other side: and wind two ends of the thread onto the needle in the lower part, and let them be lengthwise: and tighten the athil tightly.
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then knot the thread, and extract the needle.
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all atelis, and let go from them one: nor its own, so that it may run out of it superfluity of blood.
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then put over the anus a cloth soaked in rose oil, or oil of cedar, and place it over the anus: and bid the sick man to rest.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then let it go, until it falls.
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When therefore they fall asleep, care for them with ointment and the rest of healing until they are healed.
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	On the treatment of fissures.
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	For many times indeed they happen from drying of dung, and constriction of nature.
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	When therefore they do not heal, and medicine does not work on them: then it is necessary that you scrape with the point of a spatula, or with your fingernail, until they become moist, and the outer skin which prevents their consolidation be removed from them.
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then care for them until they are consolidated as is necessary.
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	If they do not knit together: then again dress them with more intense reason than the first, until they bleed much, and then they are scraped, and afterwards take care of them until they heal.
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	On the treatment of inversions of the alar cartilage, both inverted and not inverted; and of Athelil (cartilaginous growths) and Formicae (benign tumors).
Caput LXXXII.	Chapter LXXXII.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	Know that Almirmar is nothing but a round knot according to the color of the body, similar to the head of a nail: and it occurs in the whole body, especially in the lower parts of the feet, and fingers: and pain occurs with them when walking.
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	Therefore it is necessary that what is around the nail be cut and held with forceps or a hook, and eradicated from its root.
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then take care of it; and if you wish, cauterize it according to what preceded in its chapter.
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	From the athellium, however, there is one small prominence, rough, filtered, round on the surface of the body.
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And many times happen in the hands of children.
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And its cure is, that you extend the [afflicted area], and cut it: or bind it with a silk thread: or with hair, until it falls off.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you wish, cauterize it according to what has been said before with fire, or with a sharp medicine: and now the athelil are eradicated, both inverted and not inverted with the instrument which I shall tell you about.
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	A sting from an ant is also a small eminence filtered and coarse on the surface of the body, penetrating deep: and when it finds cold in it, it feels like a bite from an ant in it, and it happens throughout the body: and most of it happens in the hands.
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And its cure is, that you take a tube from the feather of a goose, or the feather of a strong hawk: and place that tube over the Ant, until the circle of the tube contains it from its parts.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then roll your hand with a probe until you cut what is around the ant: and place it deep in the flesh, and eradicate the ant from its root.
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, make it with a tube of air, or iron, according to this form.
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let the upper part of the tube be drawn up to a height so that the grip on the finger is relieved and its turning is easier.
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you wish to cauterize a Fornica according to what was previously stated in the cauterization of Aethil in the chapter on cauterization.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	On the forms of instruments that are administered to the bowels in ailments of the anus, and the solution of the belly, and colic.
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter LXXXIII.
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	Sometimes a clyster is made from silver, or from electrum, or from cast copper, or hammered copper.
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And sometimes these instruments are made small and large, according to those in which they are administered.
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	Therefore, what is administered in the cure of young children should be little, and those whose anuses are weak or painful, so also their genitals.
Clistere magnum.	Large enema.
Cistere paruum.	Small bladder.
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	Its shaft, that is, the upper part in which the uterus is tied, should be wide according to this method: and let there be a distinction so that the uterus may be tied as you see, and its lower end which enters the anus, be closed, that is, not open, smooth, gentle, drawing to subtlety: and on one side of it there are two holes, and on the other side one hole.
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	And let the width of the opening be according to the thickness of the rays, and a little thicker, and let it be one in which medicines are placed from the bladder of an animal; or from sheepskin, which is according to the shape of a small asphodel: whose root is one palm.
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	And it is pierced with many holes as it revolves, and let the space that is between every hole be the thickness of a finger.
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert into those openings a strong thread from raw fiber, which is to be of ten threads, or about that many, and tie it together with it like the lining of a bag.
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When therefore it is placed in that (the womb), it is tightened at the head with a clyster between two distinguishing constrictions with strong force.
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then give him an enema.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	And this is the form of the circle of the uterus here depicted, and the foramen.
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of administering a clyster with it is this: that you fill the rectum or bladder with medicine, which has been heated according to the amount that the patient can tolerate; and beware that it is not too hot or too cold.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the patient is laid on his back and his legs are raised to a higher position; and beneath him there is placed a thing called  *inthan*, that is, leather upon which men lie, or linen.
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then anoint the extremity with oil, or with egg white, or with flaxseed mucilage, or something similar.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then introduce it into the anus with ease.
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then let the attendant take the womb with both hands and press it vigorously until all that is in the intestine is evacuated.
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then remove the clyster and let the sick person raise his legs against the wall.
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	If medicine compels him to an outlet, then let him hold it as much as he can.
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps with it all night, it is more useful in healing.
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	If however you give him enemas in diseases of the belly, and his death is hastened, then repeat the enema until he recovers.
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	If there are hemorrhoids or painful boils in the anus, then let there be a gentle, subtle enema, from enemas which are used for children.
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this be the form of a fine clyster for that which is strict skin.
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	On the treatment of wounds of the head without fracture of bone.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Chapter LXXXIV.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have said in the division of the cure of wounds what was fitting for the book, and I will say here the cure of them with hand, and with medicines according to complement.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	Therefore I say that wounds are diversified according to how they are made, and according to the place upon which the wound falls.
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	The things therefore by which wounds are made very often, are such as a stone cast: or the cutting of a sword: or knife: or a blow with a spear, or wood, or arrow: and similar things from many such.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	Wounds that are made according to the places of the body are, such as a wound that falls upon the head, or neck, or chest, or belly, or thigh: and similar ones from those limbs.
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am telling of the treatments of some wounds, that I may put that reasoning and rule over the rest of the wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I begin with simple head wounds: for the memory of compositions will come at the beginning of the third chapter.
Dico ergo.	Therefore I say.
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When a simple wound occurs in the head and there is no fracture of the bone: consider then, if it is from a stone thrown or something similar, and has only broken the skin: and the wound is large, and fear the bad outcome of a hot abscess: then hurry, and immediately perform a cephalic phlebotomy: and do not delay this: and draw out of it blood according to the quantity of its power: if nothing prohibits phlebotomy, especially if it is blood that flows from the wound little.
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let phlebotomy be performed from the opposite side of the wound.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the sick person beware of repletion, and wine, and heavy foods.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	If something prevents a reduction, then it should be reduced by food, and it should not be brought near meats, nor wine.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And place over the wound if a hot abscess occurs, a poultice infused in rose oil alone, or with wine in which there is astringency.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	If you are certain about the hot boil, then place over the wound, if it is fresh with its blood, and has not yet changed the air, the powder which I will tell you about after a little while: and if it has already changed the air, then place on it some ointment until it heals.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	If, however, the wound is large, or is from a sword cut, and similar things: and its lips do not gather together by means of little threads, then gather them themselves with sutures, according to what I shall tell in wounds of the belly about their sutures.
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	If now a wound has been detected by the bone, and it hangs, and there is no retention of it, except in a small suspension; then cut into it.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then care for the wound with medicines, and restore in it hard flesh in the place of skin, and instruct the infirm person to be nourished with foods that are thick, such as heads and cooked wheat, until it is like porridge; and similar things.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If you find in the skin putrefaction, and it does not adhere to bone, then cut out the whole putrefaction, and throw it away; then take care of it.
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	If in these wounds is an artery or a vein from which blood flows, and it is not cut by medicines, then inquire about the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If therefore you find it not cut, then cut it with a Spatula, or bind it.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If necessity provokes when that which we said does not help, then cauterize it until the blood is cut off.
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If these wounds are small and simple, then their treatment is easy and light: so that you apply this powder over them; because it consolidates them before they change in air.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Mode of Powdered Flesh.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take one part of olibanum, two parts of dragon's blood, and three parts of unburnt quicklime: grind the whole thing thoroughly, and sift it: then fill a wound with it, and constrict it well with a good band until it adheres well to it and clots with the blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then bind it above with pads and release it, and do not loosen it while it remains, so that it does not gape open.
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For it is not removed from him medicine, until he is healed.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And sometimes it does this alone, when you do not have frankincense at hand, and dragon's blood also performs the same operation in many of the large wounds, when it is suitable to be placed upon them and bound, and are fresh wounds with their own blood, which has not been changed by air.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	If it has already been changed by some kind of alteration, especially when it is in summer time, then there is no point in the application of this powder: therefore take care of it with what we have said, so that you place on top of it some medicinal ointments: or place on top of it poultices made from barley flour, mixed with water and honey, until they discharge pus.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for the rest of the treatment until they are healed.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	If it happens with a wound and fracture in the bone, and it is small, then remove it with forceps; and now I will speak about the cure of fractures of the head as it will be later on.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	On wounds of the neck.
Caput LXXXV.	Chapter LXXXV.
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	If a wound occurs in the neck, then there is no difference in treatment between it and a wound on the head when it is simple.
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	If a nerve of the neck or an artery has already been cut, if it is a nerve, there is no use in curing it unless its treatment is carried out with something that causes strong clotting, such as ziniar and zegi and similar things.
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	Because they harm nerves and contract them.
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And you shall not place anything cold upon the wound at all; because the substance of nerves is cold, and its continuation is with the brain, which is most sublime of the members; and let it be treated as healed with medicines mild, such as chalk washed with sweet water several times infused with oil, or with rose oil, and turpentine, and when it is also washed with sweet water: and other mineral stones, in this way, and moist ointments.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	If the wound is large, then administer sutures: or tie together its edges with a ligature.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for him until he heals.
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	If now the depth of a wound is great, or if there is a cavity in the lower part of it, in which pus has already gathered, then pierce it in a more depressed place within it.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	If already cut in a wound is an artery and its blood flow has been followed, then separate, or dry it, and bind it: or cauterize it if necessity requires it.
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	If now the spondele of the throat has fallen in, or the whole, and the wounds have been healed: then gather the lips of skin with suture above the stem of the throat, and do not touch the throat, indeed make it equal to itself, and reduce it back to its natural figure.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then tighten it with a proper bandage, and leave it for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with an ointment that has astringency and drying properties until it heals.
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	If the wound has already made an impression on the bone, then examine it; and if there are fragments of bone in it, remove all of them, or as many as you can; and what cannot be prepared, leave it until the wound putrefies, and its discharge separates and is relieved.
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	If the wound is fresh, then sprinkle powder on it which I have recounted.
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	If however a bone is seen in the wound, and a fistula forms, then care for it with that one whose memory comes to mind in its chapter.
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	On a wound in the armpits.
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter LXXXVI.
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If it is a wound from a lance or knife, and you see its depth, then consider it.
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If therefore wind proceeds from the wound, when he breathes out of it who is ill, then know that the wound is mortal.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	If it is not deep and is fresh with its own blood: then do not put powder in it from the first hour, nor bind it, so that the blood is not retained in its depth, and returns to the heart, and kills the sick person; but put ointment on it, and dissolve it twice a day.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	If ointment is not present to you, then put into the opening of the wound a worn cloth, so that it may draw out what comes forth from it from the moistures; and make that the sick person sleep upon the wound, so that it may heal which gathers in it.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	If now three days or more have passed from the wound, and no spasms occur to the sick person, nor an evil tremor of the heart, nor stricture in breathing, and you see the rest of his dispositions good, then know that the wound is safe.
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Therefore care for it itself and with permissions, and the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	If, however, healing is excluded and it is always opened, then know that a fistula has already been made.
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Therefore, care for it from its own chapter.
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from a sword or knife cut and is simple on the surface of the chest or back: then treat it with what preceded regarding suture, if it is large; or with powder, if it is small.
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	If, however, he has already made an imprint in the bone, and a fragment has come out of it: then inquire about the wound, and hasten to remove those fragments, if they are separated.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	If they are not separated, then leave them until the wound putrefies, for extraction will be easier.
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	The judgment of accidents of wounds in the remaining members is in the cure as we said.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	On wounds of the abdomen and the exiting of the intestines, and their emergence.
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter LXXXVII.
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	The rupture which happens to the belly, is great, and medium, and small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	Therefore, sometimes a large intestine, or number of intestines, emerges.
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Therefore it is made with an introduction of them, and their sewing stronger and more difficult.
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And a small rupture is also difficult to repair in another way.
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	Therefore, it follows that the reduction is more difficult if you do not hasten in its introduction to its place immediately; because it inflames, opens, and grows larger; therefore the entrance into it becomes difficult.
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Therefore, a middle disruption of ruptures is better because with it the reduction of the intestine is not difficult, as it is in these two kinds.
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	Know that the suture of the vulva is according to four modes.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two common sutures are used in the suture of the abdomen, and in the suture of other wounds of the body: and two other sutures properly communicate with the rest of the wounds.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	But they are more proper with sutures of the abdomen: and I tell you each one with an explanation, and a declaration.
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I say therefore, that when a wound is small and something comes out of it from the intestine, and it is difficult to reduce it: then this is because of one of two modes.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Or because of the smallness of the rupture, as we have said; or because there is inflation in the intestine because of the coldness of the air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When therefore that is so, then it is necessary that you heat it, so that you submerge a sponge, or a humid cloth in lukewarm water alone.
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or boil it in water with squill, and cypress, and cumin, and embrocations with it the intestine until the inflation is resolved.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	Sometimes it makes wine which has astringency: and it is better than water alone in resolving swelling.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When therefore you see that the swelling has already been resolved, then moisten the intestine with water in which the quince or mallow has been boiled.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For that the entrance of it may be eased with a small thing.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	If, however, his return is excused after this cure, then find in the rupture a little, with the instrument with which hemorrhoids are cut.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	And the first cure is better when it is prepared than when it is cut; and no force should be used to cut after necessity and lack of instruments.
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let there be a part of it which is twisted, sharp, and another part of it not sharp, and the thin end be not as fine as that of a spatula, but rather be a little duller; and it is like a caida, as you see.
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When therefore the wound is enlarged and enters the intestines, then it is necessary that there be a reduction of it according to its natural form in its proper place, if possible above it: because it is better.
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	When a rupture is widespread in the lower part of the abdomen: then it is necessary that you make the sick person lie on his back, and place his legs higher than his head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the belly, then place its head and breast higher than its lower parts.
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	And similarly if there is a rupture in one of the two parts of the belly, then put your attention and your consideration always on this, that the part in which is the wound be higher than the other part.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And so it is necessary that you administer this in large wounds and in medium-sized wounds.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	In small wounds however, place it as it is prepared for you.
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make it that there be present among your hands a pious assistant, who shall hold the entire rupture with his hand: and bring together its lips.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then cover up from that he who follows the suture something after something: and this is the way of common suture of one.
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And it is, as you receive an awl, or a number of awls according to the quantity of width of the wound.
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then release from the end of the rupture the quantity of the ring finger, that is, of the doctor; and fix one point with a needle, besides which you insert a thread in the two extremities of the skin, with the two extremities of the fascia that is under the skin from the insides, until you make it penetrate from another part, and you have already gathered together two extremities of skin, and two extremities of fascia: and four orders are made.
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then bind with double thread around the wound, several times from two parts simultaneously, until the two lips of the wound are united by a decent gathering.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then let go of the thickness of the finger also, and place another point in it; afterwards tie it with a thread, as you did with the first point.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Therefore, do not cease doing this with him as much as you need from the awl until you complete the constriction of the whole wound.
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And let the needles be of medium thickness between size and fineness; because fine needles very quickly pierce the flesh: and thick ones are difficult to enter the skin; therefore they ought to be of medium thickness and size.
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	And it is not proper that a needle be fastened in the two extremities of the skin too much: so that flesh may not be cut quickly, and the wound may not open before its consolidation, and also that they may not be lengthened with the suture, so that the wound may not be prevented from consolidation.
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut the end of the awl so that it does not harm the sick person in his sleep: and put small pads made of cloth on every side of them, which will hold the ends of the awls: and let them go until you know that the wound is already healed.
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	This kind of suture with needles is more suitable for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	For it suffices in stitching them one needle, or two, or about as many.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	The second kind of suture is common, as it joins the extremities with four sutures: two extremities of skin and two extremities of fascia in one place, with a needle on which there lies thread equal in fineness and thickness.
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have pierced with the point these four extremities, withdraw the point from the part from which you began, so that the thread held up from the superior part of the wound may fall: so that it is a suture, like a suture of cloth that is tightened by tightening cloths, and put between each suture the amount of thickness less than that of the smallest finger.
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	These people know this suture.
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And with this suture I treated the wound that had happened to a man in his belly, who had been wounded with a knife, and the wound was one palm wide: and about two palms of the intestine had come out from the middle intestine, and there was a rupture in the middle of the belly.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	Therefore I reduced it after having stood the intestine of him outside the wound for twenty-four hours.
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	Therefore the wound was consolidated in a space of about fifteen days: and I took care of it, and it healed: and he lived after it for many years, converted to his dispositions.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the physicians had judged that he would not be healed.
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	And it was a marvel that I did not treat it with ointment.
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Because I was in a place where there was no ointment, nor anything of medicines.
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	Therefore I placed upon the old ulcer a poultice twice a day, and diligently washed it with honeyed water until it was healed.
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	I will say two kinds of sutures proper according to the account of speech.
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And it is, as you begin with a sharp suture: and insert the point from the outer to the inner part.
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When therefore a needle penetrates the skin and enters the flesh following the length and width of the whole body: let go of the end of the needle on the side where you inserted it, and make it penetrate into the other end from the interior part to the exterior in the other extremity miraculously.
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When therefore you have made it penetrate, then make it penetrate according to this in the same extremity marvelous from the outside part to the inside: and let go the extremity ifac, which is on this side, and make penetrate the point in the other extremity from the inside part to the outside: and make penetrate with the penetration that you make it penetrate in ifac extremity marvelous, which is in its part, until it penetrates into the whole.
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then begin also from this same side, and sew it with its extremity which is on the other side, and extract the point from the skin which has penetrated it.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then put it back into that skin, and sew its extremity which is on the other side, with this extremity marvelously: and take it out of the skin which is on its part, and make it one piece, and another: and make it one piece after another, until you have finished all its outer part according to this example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the sum of this suture is that you make your sutures with skins thinner than those which are skins: so that you bring one end to one extremity of the skin and let it go on the other side until you complete it.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second kind of suture, as Gale has said.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This speech of his is narrated as if he were to gather together all parts according to the similarity which certain physicians have, so that they gather every part to its own corresponding part by nature; and apply the end of sifac to its other end, and the end of mirach to its other end.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And that is done as I tell you.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	You ought to place a sharp point at the end of a trocar near the extremity from the outside, and make it penetrate to the inside in that alone: and let go the two extremities of the trocar.
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then roll back the point and make it penetrate from the outer part to the inner in two extremities, namely on both sides.
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then turn both [sides] over, and also make them penetrate from the inner part to the outer, into two opposite extremities.
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this method of suture is a better suture than the common one, and it is the suture whose previous description was given.
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is therefore also the word of Galen.
Et dixerunt quidam.	And some said.
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The suture of the abdomen should be made with two needles.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	That is, to introduce into both one thread: and begin with the introduction of a needle, from that which is with you, and make it penetrate to the other side, according to the suture of those who are equally matched skin.
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And know that when a rupture is in the middle of the belly, then its suture is more difficult than of the rest of the places of the belly.
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	The judgment of treatment of a wound is the judgment of the rest of wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	That is, because when you obtain a fresh wound with its blood, before air alters it; and you reduce the intestine, and your own, and make it fit: then place over it powder of earth.
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	If the air has already altered the wound: then place over it some ointment that you have present, until they make pus: and let the strands fall away, and consolidate the skin, and marvel at it.
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it as is the cure of other wounds, until it heals.
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	If medicines are not present to you, then put upon it immediately, from where it begins to emit pus, an old cloth: and change it twice a day, as I have taught you, until it is healed.
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not need other medicines in many cases when wounds are simple.
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	If you fear that the wound will communicate to the principal limbs through injury, then it is necessary to submerge soft wool in oil tempered with warmth, or in rose oil; and place it in the region of the places which are between the groins, and under the armpits.
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	If he feels pain, or punctures, or putrefaction in his bowels (for this often happens), then cleanse him with a wine clyster, thick, black, warm: especially if the rot has already reached the intestine, and an exit wound has been made reaching to its concavity.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that what is from the large intestine is of easier healing; and that which is from those finer ones is of more difficult healing.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	The intestine called the jejunum does not receive healing from a wound that happens in it at all: and this is because of its multitude, which is from veins, and its magnitude, and because of the subtlety of its body, and the closeness of its nature to nerves.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	If what proceeds from the wound is a zither, and you find it fresh: reduce it according to your reduction, which you use to reduce intestines evenly.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If, however, the space has passed and it is already green or black: then it is necessary that you tie it with a thread above the place which has darkened from it, so that there does not occur a flow of blood.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	In the wrist there are veins and arteries.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut what is beyond that ligament, and place two pendant thread ends from the lower part of the wound outside it: so that the traction on top of you may be relieved, and its extraction in case of a zirbi, and the discharge of pus from the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Remembering a wound that happened in the intestines
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When rupture occurs in the intestine and is small, it is possible for it to be restored in some people; because I saw someone who was wounded in his belly with a blow from a lance, and the wound was on the right side of the stomach, and the wound was old; and a fistula was made, and discharge and flatulence came out of it.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	Therefore I made treatment until I was not confident in his healing; and I did not cease to treat him carefully until he was healed and the place was consolidated.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	After I saw that the place was already consolidated, I feared for the weak part, that an evil accident might happen to the weak part in his belly: and no evil accident happened to him from that.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And he remained in better dispositions, eating and drinking, and resting, and entered the bath, and exercised in his diets.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And now some experimenters have said that when a wound happens in the intestine and it is small, then it ought to be ligated according to this method.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And it is, as you would take ants of large heads.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound, and place a single ant with an open mouth on top of the two lips of the wound.
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When therefore he takes hold of it and tightens his mouth, cut off its head, for it adheres and does not loosen.
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another ant near the first one, and do not cease doing this with an ant after each ant according to the quantity of the entire wound.
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then reduce it and suture the wound.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	For those heads remain attached in the intestines until the intestines are fed and healed, and no further harm befalls the sick person.
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And now it is possible to suture the intestine even with a fine thread: which has been taken from the intestine of an animal and attached to it after it is inserted into the needle.
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And it is, that you may take the end of this thread from the intestine, and it shall be much un-fleshed.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then a ligature at its extremity with a fine thread of linen wrapped.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then introduce that thread into the point, and sew with it the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then reduce it back into its parts.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this method of suturing with ants and intestine is only according to the way of trust and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	Know that a wound which is large and wide, especially if it is in one of the slender intestines, then there is no skill except subtlety, and there is no cure at all.
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	On the care of fistulas and carbuncles.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter LXXXVIII.
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	Know that every wound, or abscess when it grows old and becomes antiquated, and becomes an ulcer, and does not heal, and emits pus always, and is not cut off: then it is called universally in any limb a fistula, and we call it Zuchemen.
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula indeed is truly a knot filtered, hard, white: with which there is no pain, to which there is the concavity of a bird's feather: and because of this some call it Risati, that is, feather.
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And there are some hours which are moist, that it emits pus.
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps moisture is divided in certain hours.
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And sometimes this humidity is much, and sometimes little; and it is coarse, and sometimes fine.
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I have already said in the division, when I spoke of wounds, that every ulcer which does not heal, and in which no flesh is born, is not because of one new cause.
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	One of these is because of the small amount of blood in the body; or because of its malice; or because between it and above its lips there is hard flesh, preventing the birth of flesh; or because there is a lot of dirt and filth; or because an ulcer within itself is putrid, and the matter sent to it is of bad quality; or because the medicine is unsuitable in its treatment; or because corruption falling in the region is a type of plague; or because of the property of the region, as happens in Caesaraugusta; where digestion of illnesses is difficult, and the healing of abscesses is delayed by nature; or because it has one bone, or a number of bones.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have now shown all these causes and signs of them, and their cures with medicines in division: and it is necessary here that I make you know the cure of Fistula and Zuken, which is done by way of operation with the hand.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	Know therefore that fistula occurs in all members of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For among these are fistulas that come to the large veins and arteries, or nerves, or fascia, or to the intestine, or bladder, or to one of the ribs, or to one of the vertebrae of the back, or to one of the joints composed in composition: such as the hands, and feet: and from these there are those that go to the proximity of the principal member, and similar ones.
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	Therefore, according to this method, fistulas are from ailments difficult to heal and do not receive treatment, and dealing with them is labor and ignorance.
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	If it is from a fistula of which the depth does not reach these places which I have said: and you hope, and trust in its cure, and wish to reach the knowledge of it, then take a probe of copper, or iron, if the fistula extends in a straight line, and examine it with it.
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	If there is a winding shape in a fistula, then investigate it with a thin lead probe.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	Because lead, because of the softness of its body, is lifted and bent around a curve.
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	If a fistula has many openings, it is not possible for you to point to it with a probe.
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore, make a clyster from those openings out of their openings.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For humidity which you apply with a clyster into it, flows through other openings and runs out of them.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then inquire carefully according to the way it is possible for you: so that you may know whether there is a bone or a nerve, and whether the fistula's cavity is distant or near: or whether it is one fistula which has many openings, and stay over all of it, with the utmost strength of yours: with your questioning, by whom you question the sick person, and finding pain upon compression with your hand on the place, and similar signs and causes of accidents to abscess.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When therefore you stand over all these things truly, then go to the cure according to confidence: and it is, that you consider then, if there is a Fistula appearing nearby, or in a place safe far from the joint, or from the nerve, or artery, or vein, or one of the places which I told you: then dry the Fistula according to what was previously stated from my narration, and remove what is in it from the filtration, and corrupted flesh, which is born in its opening from flesh, or pus, and similar things: and take care of it until it heals.
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	If however the fistula is of great depth, and is according to straightness, then it is necessary that you cut it in depth as much as is possible for you.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then cleanse it from all its corrupted flesh.
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then administer a linen cloth wrapped in sharp medicines: and introduce it as far as the cavity of the fistula which you comprehended with iron: do this several times until the sharp medicine corrodes all that remains in the cavity of the fistula from corruption.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore it with ointments that generate healthy flesh until it heals.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	If it does not heal by that means, then cauterize it according to what we have narrated.
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If therefore the cause of the fistula is bone, and it is confirmed to you; then inquire into it, and dry it according to what I have told you; if nothing hinders you from a vein, or nerve, or principal member, as we have said.
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If therefore a bone is shown to you, and there is something of corruption and blackness in it: then scrape it, until the whole corruption is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with it that he may be healed until it is incorporated.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	If it does not heal and discharges pus as it used to do: then you will know that you have not arrived at the complete eradication of corruption.
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Therefore, cleanse it again carefully, and make a precise reason for it, and purify it with your utmost strength.
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore him.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If therefore it heals, it is good; and if not, then you know that that corruption is in the deep distant part of the body, which you have not reached.
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	Therefore there is no skill for you in it, unless you leave it to nature.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	If a small bone is broken, and it is possible for you, draw it together with fine forceps that are suitable for it.
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If there are many bones, then make an exact traction of them all, and do not let anything slip from them with your strength.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If something is hindering you from the dampness and there is no fear or mistake in the incision of it, then cut those dampnesses and flesh, if they are there, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If you do not have the preparation to remove the bone from your hour, then place over the wound that it may rot; and dismiss it until it rots what is around those bones of flesh and moisture.
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And guard the wound so that it does not close up.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And the section which you cut in your operation should be tightened.
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	If you are afraid, place on top of it a sponge submerged in sulfur rubbed with oil: or a sponge submerged in Egyptian ointment, or some ointment of viridity.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when those humidities rot, and the bones separate from them, the removal of them is eased, and their drawing out.
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	If it is a large single bone, such as the femur or hip bone, and similar to these, and that which has been corrupted from it is a large part, then carefully remove it with the last rasp until the blackness and corruption are removed.
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the wound.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	If now what is in it is corrupted, a large part is corrupted, and the corruption has already reached the bone marrow, then it is necessary to saw it, and cut it entirely until the place where the corruption reaches: then care for it until it solidifies.
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you, zekken, which happened to a man in his leg: that you may put this same example and help above your operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	There was a young man, about thirty years of age, to whom pain came in his leg, caused by something that moved into it from within the body, that is, from the insides, until the matter reached the leg, and he had a large abscess: and there was no external cause for it.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	Therefore, time was extended with him due to the error of the doctors until a boil opened and many materials gathered with it.
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And after the treatment had been applied, until the leg was fistulated, and many openings were made in it: which all emitted pus, and the humors of the body.
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	Therefore a multitude of physicians treated him for about two years, and there was no wise man in the art of hands until I was called, and I saw his leg, and the materials that flowed from those openings with great flow: also all the body of the man had already wasted away, and its color was yellowish.
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	I therefore introduced a probe into one of the places of openings, and the probe reached the mouth.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I carefully examined all the openings: and I found them to be connected with each other from all parts of the leg.
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	Therefore I proceeded and cut into one of the openings until I discovered the part of the bone: and I found it corrupted: which was already corroded and blackened, and putrid, and perforated until it had penetrated to the marrow.
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	Therefore I have prepared what was discovered to me from corrupt bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I have shown that there was not in the bone except for that corruption which should be cut away and sawed.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And I had already removed it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I placed a restoration of the wound with medicinal consolidatives for a long space.
Et non est consolidatum.	And it is not set.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I examined, and found above the bone, second to the first discovery: and I found continuous corruption with the bone: and I sawed what appeared to me even from that corruption.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I tried to restore it.
Et non est restauratum.	And it was not restored.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	Therefore, I again examined it, and did not cease to cut the bone piece by piece, and attempt its restoration: and it was not restored until I cut out of the bone about one palm's breadth, and extracted it with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored him with medicines, and it was quickly consolidated and healed: and this repetition of the operation on him and its section was not necessary, except because of the disposition of the weakness of the sick man, and the smallness of his tolerance, and my fear for him about death; for he fainted in all hours from the excess of evacuation.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	Therefore he was healed with complete healing: and firm flesh was born in the place of the bone, and a good arrangement was made in his body, and his strength returned: and he turned back to his dispositions: and he did not do him any harm in walking at all.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	If however a protruding bone in the body has already been broken, then it is necessary to bind it, according to this method: and it is: that you take a ligament and tightly wind it at the extremity of the protruding bone: and command someone who will extend it upward: and place another ligament from wool thicker than the first.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind the same over the flesh which is under the bone: and extend the extremity of it so that you draw the flesh downwards: and you will expose the flesh over the place which you wish to suture, so that it does not injure the sawing.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a piece of wood, or a board beneath the bone lower in the middle because when you do this, it does not prevent cutting corrupt flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.
