And many kinds are made from them, great and small, and medium, according to the quantity of magnitude of the arrow, and its smallness, and the width of the wound, and its constriction.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	Shape of the concave implement.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the shape of the impeller for deafness.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is for the end of a hard bone as if it were a radius, so that its entrance may be eased into a concave arrow and driven with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The extremity of this thrusting tool is concave like a bird's feather, so that the entrance of the arrow into it and its impact may be eased.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On the incision of veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter XCVI.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	There are thirty veins that are customarily bled from in the body.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these there are sixteen in the head: two pulsatile veins which are behind the ears, called two Herbae; and two arteries which are in the two temples appear; and two veins which are in the two lacrimals of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes; and a prepared vein in the middle of the forehead; and a vein which is at the extremity of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two gullies which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And the two veins that are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins that are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins that are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins that are cut in the arms are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of these is Cephalica, and it is from the side of the neck: and the common people call it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And Fuscous.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Middle vein, and it is composed of the branch of the Basilica and the branch of the Cephalic; and the common people call it the vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And Basilica, and it is placed in the domestic side: and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the common people call it a vein of the belly.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the cord of the arm is placed upon the furrow, and it is that in which a vein is opened, and it is that which appears above the thumb at the incision clearly.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And Salvatella: and it is a vein which is between the annular and smallest: and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and in the foot are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the curvature of the thumb from the shady side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphena: and its place is at the heel from the inside side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the vein Nesse: and its place is at the calcaneus from the side of the heel.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg are three veins similar to those.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	On venesection of two veins behind the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	Venesection of the two veins that are behind the ears is beneficial for old catarrh, and migraine, and headaches, and old head ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of bloodletting is as I have said.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, that the head of the sick person be shaved; and the back of the head be rubbed in the place of two veins with a rough cloth by good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then let the weak person tighten their neck with a clout until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their places are behind the ears in two depressed places of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Therefore seek them out with your finger, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, there mark it with a heated seal.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take a surgical knife, and it is called Incidens.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce it under the skin until the lancet reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift your hand with the vein and skin upward, and cut the vein with the skin with an incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be the quantity of two joined fingers, or about that: and make it bleed as much as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind it with small pads, and release it, until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now he proceeds at the beginning of the book on the incision and cauterization of them.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	On bloodletting of two arteries at times.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	Of the two veins that are in two times of phlebotomy, the benefit is for ancient migraine; and to a bad cold; and to constant eye strain; and for acute effusions poured into the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of phlebotomy is as I tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The weak person tightens his neck greatly, until two veins appear to the sense with manifest appearance: and their pulse is shown under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then indeed with inlay signs.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then raise the skin from above with your index finger, and introduce the cutting knife underneath, and raise the vein from above.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it as you did in the other two veins: and make it flow blood according to the quantity of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then untie the constriction of the patient, and place your finger upon the vein for one hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then place over the same cotum and pads, and tighten it above with a strong constriction: and release it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now has preceded the remembrance of them, and their incision, and their extraction at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	On phlebotomy of the frontal vein after cephalic phlebotomy.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	A wound from a vein incision of the forehead is after a cephalic phlebotomy, to old aches of the face: and to headache, and redness: and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bloodletting is, according to what I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The weak man supports his neck with a stick until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument which is called a Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its shape.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place a sharp point which is at the head of the Fossa upon the vein itself, and strike upon it with a comb, or with some other thing in this manner: and let blood flow according to the quantity that you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then close up the wound of the patient and bind it until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes it is opened with a wide vein-cutter.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it ought not to be a sharp-edged incision of the extremity, like the rest of the incisions, but rather one of a broad edge.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And the lancet should be applied across it, because the bone is close; and perhaps the lancet will break when it is fine.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	On bloodletting of the veins in the two lacrimals.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	A wound of two veins which are in the two lacrimals of the two eyes is to the eye from scabies and redness: and it is painful in the eye, and pains in the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the bloodletting is that the weak one ties their neck with a rope.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then he will cut the vein and you shall stand over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let a phlebotomy be made transversely along a short length, with a small lancet, not too wide, for there is no flesh in the place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the lancet is too fine at the extremity, it may perhaps break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then make it flow out of the blood as much as is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place upon them a pad, and bind them together at night one, and unbind them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	On bloodletting of the veins of the nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The bloodletting of the veins of the nose is brought about by acute fever and violent phlegm and pains of the face, such as a migraine, and redness which happens on the face, especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of his phlebotomy is that the sick man tightens his own neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold his nose with your left hand, and take a fine, long lancet, and place it in the middle of his harelip, between that which distinguishes the nose according to straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Because the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary that you put your hand last with a lancet and make blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it tight at night with one bandage.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	It is indeed restored quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	On the phlebotomy of veins according to Guy de Chauliac.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	The use of two veins for phlebotomy is good for the constriction of breath, and the beginning of leprosy, and melancholy illnesses, and sores that are bad, and ulcers that are corroding, that is to say, those that are caused by herpes.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of  phlebotomy of them is that it should tighten weak under both in his neck with a bandage: and let the artificer stand over the head of the infirm, and let the infirm be sitting on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then the phlebotomist makes a vein incision of moderate length.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw out from the blood a moderate quantity, or according to what you see is necessary for that.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do similarly with the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Afterwards, dissolve the ligament, and tightly bind two veins in the middle section: so that the patient does not bleed excessively.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let her be released until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	A wound is healed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	On bloodletting from veins, by Al-Gebar.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins of Albucasis are a help for phlebotomy: because it brings relief to the mouth from alcohol and gum disease; and ulcers that are bad; and fissures of the lips, and bad ulcers, even those which are in the nose and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of bloodletting is that you make the sick person sit before you: and bind his neck with a cloth.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then roll back the lip and look at two veins: one is from the right side of the lip, and the second from the left side of it: and the demonstration of both is by the blackness of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: for in the circuit of them are veins small and black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore, make both incisions with a cutting.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If there is doubt about you, and you do not know which of them it is: then attend to the incision of the greater ones, and those more manifest.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And similarly do this with the two veins that are in the upper lip: and very much indeed is it customary to do so: and cut the two veins that are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	On Phlebotomy.  Veins under the tongue after cephalic phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	Of the two veins which are under the tongue, a benefit from phlebotomy is this: that cephalic phlebotomy is good for inflammations that are in the throat, and for pain of the uvula, and for pains of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such that the sick person should sit between your hands before the sun: and elevate his tongue, and look under his tongue on one side for a vein, and on the other side for a vein; and the color of both sloping towards blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore cut both veins: and guard, so that you do not put your hand at the last in cutting the veins.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under it are arteries, and perhaps there will be a flow of blood from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	On the three veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The veins that are cut in the arm, of which the practice of bloodletting is customary in all men, there are three.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And bloodletting is done according to two modes.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or by pricking with a broad myrtle-wood lancet: or an olive tree to the fineness of the slope: or cutting with a knife lancet, and this is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Al-Zahrawi is, which is suitable for the cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And among these there are broad and fine kinds, according to the width of the veins and their constriction. The form of the phlebotomy knife should be broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is appropriate to open the concave, full, emerging, apparent, thick veins, and those which contain thick, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this lancet is of lesser width and more delicate tip.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is fitting for phlebotomy of the veins delicate, which contain blood fine and yellowish.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	On Phlebotomy in Basilica
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The basilica, which is one of these three veins, is helpful for bloodletting.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from ailments that are in the throat and neck, because it follows the chest, and the belly: and it behooves the phlebotomist with the phlebotomy, that he beware, and be above fear from it for under it is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he errs, and adds in the incision of a vein, he will cut that artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary that she be not lanced with a sharp lancet; rather let it be cutting with an Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If Basilica does not appear with manifest appearance, then it is necessary that one take the same from elsewhere and change it to another, or seek out some branch of it; or cut a vein in the arm instead of its place.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is manifest and dry it with the phlebotome Anesil, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you wish to perform phlebotomy on him, then it is necessary before the constriction of the arm, so that you touch the place until you know the place of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then signs over the place with wax, then the arm, and dry the vein with a concave incision with the Alnesil lancet, as we said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And take care that the blow does not fall through the space from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, when you tighten the ligature, an inflation at the place which you marked with the cautery, then that inflation is the inflation of the artery: therefore avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see blood rising in phlebotomy like a boy's urine, and it is thin blood, red: then you know that it is from the artery's blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Therefore hasten, and place your finger upon it for a long space, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore blood is cut (for it is often cut), then bind the arm and let it go: and let the sick person beware of movement of it: and be above his fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And let it not be moved for several days until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If blood does not cease flowing and overcomes you, and medicine is not present at the moment for you, then cut the artery if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities are contracted, and blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a piece of fisetum bark and pound it fine; take half of it, and bind it over the place of the vein constriction appropriately, with a ligature and pads until the next day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not so: then care for it with him whose predecessor was remembrance of the place of dust cutting off blood flow: and the cutting off of his blood is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the small place of the wound, and the possibility of tying from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On the vein for bloodletting, the Fusca.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The veins of the arm are beneficial for bloodletting, because they draw blood from the upper part of the head and lower part of the body: because it is composed of the Basilica branch and the Cephalic branch, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is fitting for the phlebotomist that he be above fear from his phlebotomy, for under it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds in the puncture of phlebotomy, and finds a nerve, it happens in it numbness, and difficult becomes its healing, and perhaps not healed fully.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve appears many times to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If it is hidden in some men and is subtle and does not show itself: then you must place your phlebotomy there where you will make the incision with the Alnesil and deviate the nerves with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If a vein is between two nerves, then find the vein in length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	On the cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The phlebotomy of the cephalic veins is a benefit because it draws blood from the head and brings it to aid eye ailments.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this vein properly, if you wish, that a phlebotome be used to puncture it with an olive-wood phlebotome, or with a myrtle-wood phlebotome: because it is the safest of all veins, because there is no artery beneath it, nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	Nevertheless, it is fitting for you in phlebotomy, that you avoid cutting the head of the lizard only with the lancet, and seek a softer place: and it does not harm him if, when the first percussion is not found, to repeat over it with the lancet several times.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Nevertheless perhaps a boil may arise in certain men when it is not cut out in the first percussion, but it does not harm him in any way.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the usefulness of phlebotomy, and the precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy, and its accidents from it, which you ought to consider in its correction.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First of all, it is important for you to know that phlebotomy is not administered unless it is for the preservation of health and its persistence, and caution against the arrival of illnesses.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And that a phlebotomy is made in one of the three veins which are in the elbow, namely Cephalic, and Black, and Basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And that venesection may be performed at the beginning of Spring on an empty stomach, in summer, and in autumn, and in winter after a meal, when signs of fullness appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And a bloodletting should be performed on the first day, or on the third day, after three hours have passed.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Bloodletting, which is administered in illnesses, does not have a determined hour: but when it provokes convenience and necessity to that, at night, or day, and at every hour, and at every time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not right that boys should be bled until they reach fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	A pregnant woman should not be bled except from the fourth to the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	The elderly, who have passed sixty years, should not be bled.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When therefore someone wants to undergo phlebotomy for any reason, it is necessary that he cleanse his bowels before phlebotomy with a gentle enema if there is much feces retained in them: so that the veins at phlebotomy do not draw up putrid superfluities from the intestines harmful to the principal members.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should a patient who is vomiting be bled, that is, suffering from nausea, nor one who has been drinking too much, nor one who is recovering from drunkenness, until that is removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor one with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let phlebotomy be avoided again after colic passion, and vomiting, and flux of the belly, and multiplication of intercourse, and labor, and exercise, and vigils, and fasting, and all that dissolves the strength from the body or animal.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of humors before that, if blood is thick with food and drink, and medicines: if it is possible for it.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then he should enter the bath, if nothing prevents him; or he should exercise in some way, so that the blood may be made more subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place his phlebotomy in his chest, around the third day, as we have said; and try, so that his chest may be emptied on that day of all animal bad accidents: such as constriction, and anger, and fear: and from all bodily accidents, such as labor, and punishment, and superfluity, and those similar.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him make his seat to be present with things of which use men have grown accustomed from fragrance, and smell, and frolic, and similar ones in the amount of possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the bloodletter sit on a stool which is higher than the patient's bed; afterwards he shall draw out his arm and rub it with his hand two or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then tighten the ligament with corrections, and wrap it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the constriction be moderate, because when a constriction is unequal, either by excess in the constriction, then it prevents the course of blood; or in softening, then it also prevents the course of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the constriction, it is necessary for the one cutting to rub his hands together until the veins swell and become evident to the sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the surgeon removes the leech with a little oil, properly old.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he places his index finger of the left hand over the vein in the place where he wants to perform phlebotomy, lightly: so that the vein does not escape and the percussion may fall.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Because the vein is like a fleeing string in phlebotomy; and from them is that which is full of windiness; and when you place the phlebotomist upon it, it contracts under the phlebotomist, and the phlebotomist is deceived, and does not open the vein; and if he opens it, it is strict; therefore it is necessary that the phlebotomist be firm and solicitous in all these things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he puts down the lancet.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If therefore a vein is opened from one vice, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat this under another place a little below it, or above it with haste; if the place does not suppurate.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If it is suppurating or a weak person flees, then dismiss him on the day or two days, and do not tie a bandage tightly.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps it will draw a hot abscess.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	He should not enter a bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then he would repeat bloodletting, if he wished.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small, or blood flows gently: and you fear that the quantity of blood which you desire will not come forth; then repeat the incision into the wound according to straightness, and add little to the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this with haste, before the place becomes closed up, for a closed place is found in many men at the time of a minor operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If therefore you see the abscess itself, then do not return upon it at all, for it excuses nothing before you.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place over it something of the oil of feces; because it will alleviate the course of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than oil itself, and than the rest of the olive.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer the feces of oil in all your bloodletting, wherever you cut veins to prohibit the flow of blood; and they make this from tyriaca alfarach, and sagzenea, when it is placed over the place from one of them.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood is refined and dissolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If a large abscess occurs at the site of incision, which often happens, especially to those who are not routinely bled or have only a small vein opened, then quickly place a sponge soaked in hot water and salt over the area and bind it for one hour, because it will loosen.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do this after the blood has exited from the very vein, with its completion, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If something remains in place after days, some blackness or greenness, it does no harm: and if you wish, put on top of it something of aloe, or myrrh dissolved, or something from the juice of mint, that is, a balm or something similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And abscesses and swellings frequently occur in bloodletting at the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Therefore place your hand upon it, then if you find softness at your compression upon it, then that prominence is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, take care that you place something upon it from what we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow from it of the artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster for him with that which has astringency, that the place may be closed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with the rest of the care until he is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that you extract from every man according to the quantity of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from the color winning over blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it flow out until it turns red; and similarly if you see it thick, then let it flow out until it becomes thin; and similarly if it is sharp, until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And he who is full, strong, and needs bloodletting only once, let the incision of the vein be widened, and let the phlebotomy be broad; and in him who is weak, let it be the opposite of this.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary that he extract it with a probe, and that the hole be narrow; and it is better that what is administered in bloodletting of the vein is a transverse section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of bloodletting is safe from the flow of blood, and from the cutting of the nerve: and it is more praiseworthy, and safer than bloodletting across width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to one who is accustomed to fainting during bloodletting, it is necessary that before bloodletting he eat bread slightly soaked in pomegranate juice or boiled grains, if heated: and draw out his blood in three or four ounces.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if it is of a chilled constitution, then let him take before phlebotomy bread soaked in syrup of myrrh, or in a syrup of honey flavored with spices, or in an aromatic fragrant syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If fainting occurs during bloodletting, and the cause is the exit of much blood, then it is necessary that he should take in a drink of meat water, and a subtle fragrant syrup; and use aromatics with sea salt, and liniment his chest with it; and use the rest which we have said in the division in the chapter on fainting from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	He who wishes to bleed his arm and release his blood the second time: it is necessary for him whose phlebotomy is due to excessive evacuation and whose strength is weak, to release his blood gradually according to the amount of strength in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wants to drain his arm and loosen his blood second, and his body is strong: then let him do it after seven hours, or nine from his first incision.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wants to draw blood from his body to the opposite part to which it declines: it is necessary for him to be bled on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body there is much blood already heated, and it becomes sharp, and makes fever happen: it is necessary that the blood should leave from it in one vein, and a large quantity be drawn out of it; and the opening should be enlarged until syncope occurs; after you have kept all the conditions of phlebotomy; and so that you place your hand upon his pulse at the course of the blood, so that death does not happen instead of syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Many times indeed it happens that the phlebotomist is ignorant, and negligence falls.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not necessary when you want to loosen the arm and loose the blood a second time, when already the opening of the vein is closed and difficult exit of the blood is made, that you press upon it with vehemence, and quickly stretch out the cupped vessel.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is a grievous evil, indeed let it be left alone until it is opened by a second incision.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with the sharpness of a phlebotomy instrument that which has clotted from blood at the opening of the vein, and place upon it something dissolved salt in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place upon it something of tyriaca alfaroch, or sagzenea, and place it with a gentle compression, until the blood flows out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If a vein has already been opened in an abscess, then let it be left open and not tied up until the abscess sits.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If necessity compels bloodletting a second time and there is no excuse, then either the phlebotomist should cut above that place or in another arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The brachial vein is cut at the site of Fuscca and Basílica, if they are not found and are hidden, because it is composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of bloodletting is that the sick person should put his hand into hot water until the vein becomes red and appears plainly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then it is bound over itself with a bandage of moderate constriction in the middle.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then the incision is made with the lancet according to transversal direction, not lengthwise or laterally; and let the opening be wide, and let your incision be such that it cuts across the joint of the hand for a short distance.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If he prevents the exit of blood, then immerse your hand in hot water, and let the blood flow into the water until you achieve your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If, however, you are in the days of summer, then you are excused from the repetition of hands in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And indeed very much blood flow is put in warm water in time of winter.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And bloodletting from this vein is healthier than all veins, because there is no pulsating artery beneath this vein, nor a nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	A bloodletting of the right hand of Saluatella is beneficial for liver ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that you tie a vein with a band on the hand, or with your own hand, after you have put it into warm water until the vein swells and becomes apparent to the sense.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then with the lancet crossing it.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it entirely, it will not harm him in anything.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And preserve, so that you will not bring your hand to the vein cutter at last.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under this are the nerves of the fingers stripped of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then again the hand to the warm water, and let blood run in it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not repeat it in hot water, the blood clots in the opening of the vein, and its course is prevented.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When therefore you have extracted from the blood the quantity of necessity, then place upon the vein oil and salt: that it may not solidify quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly, it is necessary that you do with every strict branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The incision for phlebotomy from the left hand is because it is connected to spleen ailments; and similarly do so in phlebotomy as you did in the second equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The benefit of cutting the saphenous vein is for ailments that are in the lower part of the body, such as pains of the womb, and retention of menses, and infirmities of the kidneys, and ulcers of the hips and legs, old, and similar illnesses.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that the sick person puts his foot into warm water, and he makes friction upon it until the veins become swollen, and binds above the joint of the foot with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And indeed veins are located at the heel bone, appearing towards the thumb: and they branch out from it on the face of the foot many branches.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore, the phlebotomy is performed in the larger branch of the vein, or at the heel in its cluster; because it is better and more salutary.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If one cuts the vein on the face of the foot, then carefully cut away from the nerves that are below it on the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your incision for venesection as you wish to make it transversely, and let the scalpel be Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If the outflow of blood is prevented, then immerse the foot of it in warm water: and let the blood flow into it until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the vein cutter errs in the first attempt, then return with phlebotomy to the upper part for a short time, because the place is safe, and do not fear malice from it when you are careful of the nerves, as we said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the saphenous vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The location of the Sciatic veins, as we have said, is at the heel from the inside side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the benefit of bloodletting is for pain in the hip, when it is because of hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that the sick person should enter the bath and hasten: and he should bind his leg from the side of the hip to above the heel with a thin cord four fingers wide, for it does not appear otherwise.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When therefore it appears, then the phlebotomist shall cut it according to what is possible for you, or according to the direction; and it is better, or that you cut it with an incision, or sever it with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For its location is safer, and it is hidden in many people's bodies indeed.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it, and it does not appear at all to the sense: then the phlebotomist will take some branch of it, and that which appears on the back of the foot, and towards the ear; and be careful from nerves, and make it run out of blood in the quantity that you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the constriction, and place over the site of the incision skin, and bind the area.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It heals quickly indeed.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	On Wind-letting and its quality of use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter XCIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Instruments are made from horns, and from bronze, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And indeed punction is done according to two modes.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	With scarification, and drawing of blood: and another is venesection without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this kind of suction which is without incision, is according to two modes.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And there are fourteen places in the body which are treated with cupping and incisions and blood letting.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	There is one that is named Alnocrati Ventus and it is in the rear of the head: and Alkehel and it is in the middle of the neck: and Alhagdahim Ventose, and these are two laminae of the neck from two parts simultaneously: and Ventose of the mind, and it is under the mandible in the lower mouth: and Ventose of two spatulas: and Ventose Alachosos above the end of the tail: and Ventose of two focilium, and these are the middle of the two arms: and Ventose of two legs: and Ventose of two tails.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed ventosa does not draw blood from veins dispersed in the flesh, and for that reason virtue does not fall from them, as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	It is not necessary to administer cauterization, whether with fire or without fire, in certain illnesses that arise from fullness, until the entire body has been evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity compels us to perform venesection because of sickness or habit, we administer it at any hour, at the beginning of the month, at its end, and in the middle, and at any time whatsoever.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	It is because among men, when blood multiplies in him until it needs to be drawn out through venesection, he finds heaviness in his head and a headache.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And of these is he who found suppuration and redness on his face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And among these is he who finds itching in his face, and forehead, and dimness, and dullness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And there is one who cuts the place of his windpipe.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And there is one whose laughter is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And of these is one who finds a taste of blood in his mouth; or his tongue becomes ulcerated and he spits out blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And there is one whose sleep multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And among these are those who see in their sleep blood and redness, and wounds, and things similar to these.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When therefore we see something from those things, and properly if it is in the third week of the month: we prescribe then that ventilation be done, after two hours or three have passed.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	A wound of the neck from a sword thrust is: because it carries to the weight on the head, and what flows forth to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it is necessary that after evacuation of the whole body,
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this indeed is a type of  cupping in the place of cephalic bloodletting.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not permitted to use this on someone who has a cold constitution, or who has a cold.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it does great harm to him.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	Therefore, it is not proper for them to use these things, those who are old and have cold pains in their head.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	Whoever is diligent over it, forgetfulness is generated over him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for this reason it is necessary that you instruct the Ventosa to place his hand with the wind-pump briefly lower down, fearing from the production of oblivion.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Bloodletting by the Alkehel method, is in the place of phlebotomy at Fuscae and Basilicae, and because of this it induces shortness of breath, constriction of breathing, instrumental breakage, coughing, and repletion.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary that a small pump be driven by Alkehel, because if it is placed below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Bloodletting for the head calms pains that occur suddenly in the head, and also headaches, migraines, toothaches, and pain at the roots of the teeth; it is a place for bloodletting according to Basil.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary that you instruct the Operator not to press his hand with the scraping, so that he does not cut an artery and a flow of blood occurs.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Bloodletting under the chin is used for inflammation of the gums and similar ailments in the mouth; it takes the place of other phlebotomies which are in both lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The blowing of the spatula is referred to as alchafacha, which is done from reflection and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The evacuation of the interior parts by two incisions helps the phlebotomy of the three veins, Basilica, and Fusca, and Cephalic; because it draws blood from all those small veins that are in the flesh: and those small veins draw from other larger veins until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary that you instruct the Ventosator not to proceed too far in the cutting; because the place is stripped of flesh, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The suction cup, when applied to a wound, is useful for hemorrhoids and ulcers of the lower parts of the body.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary that you instruct the Ventusator to be large and of brass; because a place needs strong suction, and possibly fine Ventusators break. And let it be scraped with a deep scraping.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	Leeches on the legs diminish by manifest decrease; for they draw blood from the whole body, and bring together old pains in the kidneys, and wombs, and bladder: they cause menstruation, and bring together boils, and shortness of breath: and they stand in place of two saphenous vein openings, and other.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	Nevertheless they weaken the body a great deal, and cause syncope to happen in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the treatment of winds [of the abdomen] is similar to the treatment of winds [of the two legs].
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the instruments is that you place the instrument first empty and draw by a temperate suction. And do not prolong the position of the instruments, but put them quickly and remove them quickly so that humors come to the place with an equal arrival.  And do not cease to repeat this and continue until you see the place already red and swollen, and it appears redness of blood; then therefore scarify, and repeat the suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the arrangement of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For one who is of tender flesh and few pores, it is necessary that he be scarified once, no more, so that the place may not ulcerate.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And instruct the Ventor (suction pump), so that it may enlarge the scarification and make it slightly deep; and moderate suction in ease, and speed, and its own movement.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is a thickening in the blood, then it is necessary to scarify it twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first incision there is opened a way for the thinning and liquefaction of blood; and in the second, a thorough examination of the extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is foul indeed, then let a third incision be made so that it may come to an end.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And lastly, when we wish to draw blood gradually, or a little at a time, one incision suffices us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we want many blood extractions, we make many incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick, then it is necessary that it be scarified with a deep scarification, and an equal limit in the scarification is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What ought to be administered from oils at the positioning of the winds, and what should a wind be cautious of.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In that case, whose skin is thick, hard, dark, and whose pores are narrow, it is necessary to anoint the places of Ventosoar with oils that are opening, soothing, and dissolving: if it is in summer time, such as alkeiri oil, or violet oil, or almond oil, or oil from pumpkin seed.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in wintertime, then narcissus oil, or lily oil, or chamomile oil, or syrup: and the like.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If however the superfluity is thick and cold, then let the oil be of bitter almond, or balm oil, or alb oil, or anise oil: and the like.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If a large wound is to be cleaned, of tender flesh: then it ought to be prevented from oil, and it ought to be washed by those places of the winds after the cleansing with rosewater, or with cold water, or with solar water, or with gourd water, or with purslane water: and similar ones.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	He who has much moisture in his blood shall wash with vinegar, or myrtle water, and sumac, and the like.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	If, however, the superfluities are coarse, he shall wash his wounds with old wine, or with fig water, or with an extract of dill, or chamomile: and with things similar to these.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary that a bath be avoided, or the trace of a bath, indeed it is necessary that it be administered after leaving the bath for one hour, or for two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not necessary for someone to sleep after venesection.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is required to be regulated before venesection, either a bloodletting?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after that, you ought to consider first: then if it is  sanguineous and feverish, or if the wound is being cut (opened) by bile, and its sharpness and inflammation overpower his blood: then he ought to receive refrigerants such as pomegranate juice; and also endive with vinegar and lettuce, and secaliabinum, and iuleb; and things similar to these.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And place his food chicks and the flesh of sheep he will relish, and foods cooked with herbs: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And if its condition is cold, it ought to take in drink a syrup of honey, or of almiua, or alsecaniabin made from seeds: and let it take medium-scented wine, which is between old and new: and let it be prescribed that it use little food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And put food for him of chicks, and sparrows, that is, small birds, and young doves he should give.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that the drink on the day of bleeding and incision be greater than food; and it is necessary that in some men there be given in the drink at times tyriaca alfaroch, or medicine of musk, that is, muscata, or alesselithe before bleeding; and before phlebotomy, or after: so that the principal limbs may be comforted, and the blood may be refined.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And it is not proper that they should take it in heated drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	On Varices without Incision
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	Those which are without incisions, however, are those placed upon the liver, spleen, foot, and over the stomach, navel, and places of the kidneys, and anus; because these members do not endure incisions upon them.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And these are not sought except for either attachment from a limb of blood to a limb; such as we place the leech on the nipples in the suffering of the flow of blood of the nose.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them to release cold airiness from the limb that is unseen; such as when we place it upon the stomach and the navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For it indeed thins the limb, and heats it, and removes pain because it dissolves that windiness.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	It is also placed upon the kidneys when a calculus or stone occurs within them.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	For perhaps, by the virtue of its traction, it opens an abscess, or removes a stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And similarly he does when it is placed upon the hypochondria, and the spleen among the others should be washed in both of these.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these ventosa are administered with incisions only.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And sometimes they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes they are administered full with warm water in ailments of pleurisy: and that is, so that it be filled with a cupping glass, and be large, hot water alone, or water in which have been boiled herbs that are suitable.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	The shape of a cupping glass administered with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	Let the width of its opening be two finger-widths, according to what we have formed: and let its quantity in depth be half a palm: and let there be a small hole on its side, in the place which is about the middle of it, according to the quantity that a needle can enter into it: let it be made of copper or yellow metal, with broad, smooth, equal edges, so that it does not injure the limb upon its placement upon it: and let there be a transverse rod in its middle, of copper or iron, where a candle is placed with fire.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And now this large one is made, larger than we have narrated, and somewhat smaller than that, according to the pains and age of him who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For boys and thin people are different types of lancets than for men and stout-bodied individuals.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.
