The quality of placing this winnowing with fire on the limb is, that you set alight a wick with fire from linen properly, or a small candle from wax: and place it over the middle of the transverse beam which is in the middle of the winnowing: so that the fire may be kindled around the lower part of the winnowing, so that the body of the sick person is not burned.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then a finger is placed over the limb and over the hole that I have mentioned, until when we hold it with wind; while we need it, we remove the finger, and vapor will exit through that hole, and the wind will be immediately released.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then apply heat with a burning stick according to its measure, and repeat it if you need it.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	In the case of suction which is administered in a sickness of pleurisy with water, there is no transverse rod, nor hole; and it is not administered unless it is filled with water, and placed upon the limb only.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And this suction cup, the larger it is so that it can take much water, is better.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	On the Suspension of Bloodsuckers.
Caput XCIX.	Chapter XCIX.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Leech therapy is not administered in many cases, except where the positioning of leeches is not possible due to their small size, such as on the lip and gums and similar parts.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or in the exposed member, such as the finger, and nose, and things similar.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	And the quality of using them is: that you take them from leeches which are in sweet waters, clean from rot.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then they are put in fresh water day and night until they are famished, and there is nothing left in their belly.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then the body shall be evacuated first with phlebotomy and with ventoses.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then wipe the limb of the infirm, until it is red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Afterwards they shall be placed upon it.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	When they are therefore filled and fall and there is possible suction of the place with a windy one, then it is more ultimate in aid: and if not, then wash the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	Then with much water, it is rubbed and squeezed.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	If the flow of blood continues after the application of  blood-sucking leeches and it is still oozing, then place a linen cloth soaked in cold water on top of it until the bleeding stops.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	If blood multiplies, then pulverize upon it pounded zegi or gallic acid, and things similar to these from styptics, until the blood is stopped.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or let pads of scraped beans be placed upon the area and left there until the beans adhere to the place, because blood is stopped.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And it is necessary if repetition of bloodletting is required, when possible, to change them.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	If leeches are forbidden from being suspended, then the place should be wiped with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Or fix a point in the places until something comes out of blood.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then they are placed, for when they feel something from blood, they immediately adhere.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When therefore you wish them to fall, pulverize upon them something from pounded aloe, or salt, or ashes: and they will fall immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	End of the Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Part III.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	A universal discourse on restoration, and dislocation, and cure of torsion, and similar things.
Caput I.	Book I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This chapter is also very necessary in the art of medicine, and it is the restoration of a fracture and a dislocation of accidents in the bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	Know, O Sons, that those who are foolish among the doctors and the common people boast about this Chapter, and those who have never looked upon an ancient book nor read a letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And because of this reason, this mode is deprived of sciences in our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	And I have never found anything good in it at all, and I have not attained from it what I have attained except because of the length of reading the books of antiquity, and study over their understanding until I extracted the knowledge of it from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then by experience and study throughout the length of my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	And now I have described to you in this Chapter all that contains my knowledge: and above what has passed my experiment, after I have abbreviated it for you, and released it from the occupation of elongation, and I have abbreviated it at the end of abbreviation, and I have shown it at the end of declination: and I have formed in it many forms from the forms of instruments which are administered in it, as it is by addition of declination, as I did in the two preceding Chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	Summaries and collections are from the being of fractures of bones, from those whose preliminary is necessary, before we begin the remembrance of broken members, and diverse, of each one.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	It is necessary, as we say in the prologue to this Chapter, that the highest matters and chapters, to the understanding of which the artificer is first compelled to station himself over their truth: namely, that you, and those who are ready, may know, or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say therefore that when a fracture or dislocation or torsion or fall happens to someone, then it is necessary to hasten first of all to bleed him and to loosen him, or both at the same time: if something does not prevent it, such as weakness of strength: or he is one to whom something of these things has happened out of those children, or a decrepit old man: or the time is one of violent heat, or violent cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Then let him be content with his food, with cold herbs and the flesh of birds and hares: and forbid wine and coarse meats, and filling oneself with foods and all food that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Until you are secure from the hot abscess, and do not fear the discharge of material to the limb: then let the sick man return to his first way of life with which he is accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When therefore a broken bone begins to be restored, then it is necessary that the sick person should be fed with nourishing foods, much, thick, heavy, in which there is viscosity: such as food made from cooked wheat with water, and rye, and heads, and feet, and bellies of oxen, and eggs, and fresh fish: and thick wine, and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	With this regimen, coagulation of a fracture occurs faster and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And know that broken bones, when they are in men who are in their first old age and decrepit, it is not possible, that they may be continued and consolidated according to their own nature always, because of the drying up of their limbs: and they consolidate and continue which are from them in the end of softness, like the bones of little children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	Nevertheless, nature joins together something like glue over a broken bone from every part, which has thickness, to which it adheres and binds it until it is glued together and bound together, until it comes to the end of strength and firmness, just as it was at first, until nothing prevents it from performing its functions: and for this reason it is necessary that you put nourishment for the sick food in which there are heaviness, viscosity, and thickness, as we said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And know that the kinds of fractures are diverse, according to the diversity of limbs: because a fracture of the thigh is different from a fracture of the bone of the head: and a fracture of the bone of the chest is different from a fracture of the bone of the back: and similarly all the rest of the members exist diversely one from another: and I have come with remembrance of every kind of fracture exposed in his Chapter distinguished from another.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	And the kinds of bone fracture are also diversified within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	Because it is fractured in an arched shape, besides that stars occur in it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	And sometimes a fracture of it is made according to the length of the bone: and there are fractures of it star-shaped, that is, with stars, and additions proceeding, as are in a pen, when it is fitted with a knife for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	And not proceeding: and it is a fracture with a wound and disruption in the head: and it is a small fissure fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And every kind has a disposition or instrument proper to its restoration, according to what will come about its remembrance, distinct in its places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And from that which is known as a fracture of bone, is its crookedness, and its prominence; and its appearance to the sense, and its sound when you compress it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	When therefore there is no apparent twisting in the place, nor a sound at your touch when you touch the bone with agitation, nor does the sick person find great pain: then there is no fracture there, indeed it is possible that there is twisting, or a small fissure: therefore you ought not to move it with your hand and compression at all, rather put upon it from medicines, of which the remembrance comes, after the time which is convenient in place: then the bandage shall be tightened subtly.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And know that when the place is bent and split into two, besides which boils may occur there, nevertheless all part is removed from its pair: then it is necessary for you to begin at your hour for its rectification, leveling it before a hot abscess occurs in it.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	If however it happens to him that a hot abscess occurs, then let it be left alone for several days until the abscess rests.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	Then equal it according to whatever way can be by gentleness and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And know that its restoration and its equalization is easier than bone, in which happen wounds.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then bind it as much as you remember.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	If there are splinters in the bone, then it is necessary to extend this broken limb from two parts, if it is a hand or foot: or with your own hand, if the limb is small: or with two ropes, or with a rope and hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And let your position be such that you place the limb upon a level place, according to its natural form, until when the parts of the broken limb are extended: then try, as best you can, to return those additions to their places: and beware, according to your strength, that there does not happen pain or injury to the weak by your operation: and try, according to your strength, to apply one of the two bones with its fellow, according to better forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	And it is necessary at that hour, that you test and touch him with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	If therefore you see something different there, rectify it, and make it equal by the quantity of your virtue.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And avoid violent extension and strong compression, as many fools do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	Often indeed they cause a hot abscess or a contraction in the limb to happen through that operation of theirs, as we have already seen from their operations many times.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Then bind after the setting, and a decent operation, and stricture of that limb, and rest, and tranquility: and warn the sick person about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	And make him guard himself so that he does not move himself at the hour of his vigils, and sleep of his turning, and agitation, and evacuation, and all his movements with his last strength.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	And so that he may avoid a position of the member which is followed by pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	That is, because when he feels pain or injury in the position of a limb, then it is necessary that he changes it to another position from the one in which he does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	And be careful with it, so that its position is equal, straight: so that there does not happen twisting in the limb when it is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the constriction of the broken limb is, according to what I say.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	Know that broken limbs differ in their smallness and their size and their form.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	Therefore, if these are small things, such as an arm, and a finger, and a foot, and the like, then it ought to be a soft, fine cloth wrapping.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	Those which are gross among them, such as the hip and leg, it is necessary that there be a broad, hard wrapping on them.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	Because the broad ligament connects the large limb and binds it from every part with an equal constriction, so that it does not enter the mark.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	Then after evacuation, begin to apply a suitable ointment on top of it, in a soft sponge over the site of the fracture itself.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	Then begin to wrap the bandage over the place of the fracture with three or four turns, according to what the limb deserves: and tighten your hand a little with the bandage.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	Then go with him to the upper part from the place of the fracture, and tighten less than the tightness that you tightened the fractured place.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	Then extend yourself with the rolling from the place of the fracture for a short time, and soften the constriction gradually, until you grasp a large piece from the healthy place.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	Then take another strip of linen and wrap it again over the broken place with bandages.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	Then go with the wrapping towards the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	And let your operation be in stricture of the involution, and its softening, according to what we said in the first preceding involution.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	Then put between the folds a soft lint or cloth, with which the twisting of the fracture is equalized, if it has a twist: and if not, do not put anything in it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	Then cover over it with another bandage.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	Afterward, having made these equal and careful sutures, if there is no swelling in the place, nor a hot abscess.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	If there is swelling or an abscess in it, then place on top of it that which sits above the abscess and removes the swelling. And let it be for several days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	Then tighten over the very star itself.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	And let the probes be from the middle of a wide reed, scraped and skillfully formed; or let them be from wood out of which sieves are made, which are made from pine, or geraid, that is, branches of palm, or calingi: and let the width of every probe be, according to this form, and this same figure.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	However, the asterisk that is placed over the very lesion itself ought to be somewhat thicker and wider than the remaining asterisks, and the length of the asterisk should be according to what is fitting for the member based on its size and smallness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	Then bind over the Astella with another bandage, according to the first tightness.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	Then bind above with threads properly, according to what we said about constriction: and let it be that your constriction be above the place of the fracture more; and the more it is elongated from the fracture, the less constriction.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	And it is necessary that the threads be of medium thickness and fineness, and that they be made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	Because if the threads are thick, as I saw from the operation of foolish people who put their threads from twisted hempen cords, it is a great error because the constriction falls with them outside the quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	And fine threads do not again become suitable because you do not obtain through the stricture that which you desire.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	And it is not right that there be less than a finger's width between the stars.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	If a patient is hurt by the extremities of the instruments after constriction in healthy places: then place under them from soft wool or carmine-dyed wool until nothing is harmed from it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	When, however, there is a fracture with a wound, and rupture occurs in the skin, I will come with a remembrance of it in the second chapter according to singularity.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	And know that not every broken limb ought to be bound with splints from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	That is, because when a limb is large, it should not be placed above itself with stars [i.e., a dressing or bandage], except after five days, or seven, or more, according to your security from the event of a hot abscess.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	And this is the way of plasters, which the ancients used to restore, which are placed upon a fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	The method of a common poultice shortened, restoring a fracture, suitable for many complexions, especially women and children; because it is from that which does not overcome heat, nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	And it is, as you take from the flour mill dust, and there is marrow of flour which hangs on the walls of the mill near the movement of the millstone: and you make it like this, except that strain it with the membrane of an egg white: and place its composition not thick, nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	A mode of plaster for restoring a fracture, and dislocation, and twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	Take marshmallow, and laurel, and acacia, and enula, and mugwort: and juice of all, each ʒ X myrrh, and aloes of both each ʒ V and alethil ʒ XX are ground together, and sifted, and mixed with alethil water: or with egg white, if the complexion of the sick is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	Then use this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	For it is of good composition, restores broken bones quickly, and benefits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	Another method of poultice, which also benefits fractures and sprains.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	Take mugath and mess and white alum, each 10 grains; myrrh and aloes, each 5 grains; acacia, 6 grains; Armenian bolis, 20 grains. Grind all together thoroughly, sift them, and make a mixture with water or egg white. Administer.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	The method of a plaster for joints and bones separated from their places; and it sits the pain that happens to them, and the split of bone, and fracture.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	Take wool that has not been spun and submerge it in vinegar and oil boiled: and place it over the location.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	And in this plaster there is no virtue of restoration, but it is good in the sedation of a hot abscess: and it drives out pains properly.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	The Method of a Plaster for Restoring a Broken Bone
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	Take leaves of fig tree and leaves of wild poppy; and pound everything, and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	The mode of a shortened poultice, administered at the restoration of a bone fracture; and when you wish the dissolution of the residue of an abscess.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	Take root of althea, and chamomile, and violet flowers, and herb flour, all one part each: pound all things together, and make them into wine, unless the limb is heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	If it is hot, then make it with moist coriander water, or with water, and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	Another method of a stronger poultice for dissolving a hard abscess when restoring a limb occurs.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	Take root of althaea, and flaxseed, and balm, and melilot, and samsum, and violets flower, and chamomile, each one part, grind all together, and make with willow water, or with sweet water, or with wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	All of it according to the heat of the limb, and the quietness of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	However Hippocrates did not say in his book that a thing should be placed on a broken limb during its restoration, except for a pad made of felt and oil: nothing else; and he narrated that it should be a medium between thickness and thinness.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	Galen thought that things should be placed on the broken limb during its restoration, in which is dryness of heat, such as frankincense, and aloes, and olibanum, and similar things to those which we have mentioned.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	The method of a poultice that is applied to a wound and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Take ground lentils, and mugwort, and the hair of man cut or feathers of a bird, and oak leaves, and salt, in equal parts; pound them, sift them, and mix them together; and make an ointment from this.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	The quantity, however, according to what is necessary, when the bandage should remain, is then to consider if no pain happens to the sick man, nor itching, nor is the broken bone moved from its place: then do not unravel it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	If it should happen that there is itching, severe or restless pain, or swelling in the place: then quickly, and within the hour, dissolve and remove the dressing from it; and take a soft cloth, or a soft sea sponge, moisten it in lukewarm water, and wash the place with it until the itching subsides and the pain settles.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Then let the limb rest for an hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Then place on top of it a cloth dipped in vinegar and oil, or rose oil: and bind over it at night for one night until you are secure from the hot abscess, and the swelling of the limb rests, and the pain of it is removed.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Then lead it again to the subtle stenosis, and a small poultice: and do not bind it with your first constriction, and more subtly with it, until it heals.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, and swelling, and all accidents have been removed completely, and the indigestion has disappeared from the plaster and constriction, then treat it again as you did at first equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	If nothing of those things we said happens to a member, then you do not loosen it unless after three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when it is discharged after twenty days, the whole thing, according to what appears to you from the solution of the limb, as we said, until when the fracture adheres and the coagulation of flesh approaches above it: also add then in the constriction more than your first constriction altogether: and also add in the thickening of food for the sick, according to what precedes the recollection of it.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	If you see that the place of the fracture has already dried up and has widened more than necessary, then know that nourishment is prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	Therefore, soak it with lukewarm water at every opportunity where you have dissolved it, and let it be so for all three days, and alleviate the stricture a little.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	Therefore, through this operation nourishment flows to the limb and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	This, however, which fools who restore from a broken limb make as vice versa, when it is not restored primarily as it ought to be, and restored according to the crookedness, is an error from their operation, and great fear: and if it were straight, they would have said this in their books of old, and they would have operated upon it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	And I did not see anywhere their trace in that at all, and it is better that it not be done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	On making an incision in the head.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	There are diverse kinds of fractures, and many forms of them; and their causes are distinct.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	For from the fracture that is made by a blow with a sword: and the blow takes away the bone whole as far as it reaches to the siphac, which is under the bone, just as an axe does in wood: and because of this this kind of fracture is named Axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Or if a sword strikes something in the bone and strikes its face but the incision does not penetrate to its end, this kind of fracture is called Kalaan, that is, Absolute Leuatio.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And there is a wound of two fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	And from a fracture is, which is crushing or attrition: and its cause is a blow with a stone, or a fall upon a stone, or things similar to these.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	And this fracture is also either penetrating, which already approaches the tissue beneath the bone, or is on the face of the bone; and is a wound of these two fractures also either small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	And from fracture is this, which is hidden in the bone in the fineness of a hair: and it is a small fissure, and because of this this kind of fracture is named capillary.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	And of these there is a fracture that happens from a fall, or the strike of a stone, and things similar to it, which cause the lamina of bone to enter into the interior, and a concavity is made: just as happens to copper caldrons when they are struck, and part of them enters into the interior.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	And this is most often found in the heads of moist bones, such as the heads of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	And these are all kinds of fractures separated, and I come with remembrance of the whole thing in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	And we know all these kinds of fractures by examination upon them, and inquiry into them with probes, and removal of corrupted flesh that is upon them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	A capillary species is recognized by this, that it is uncovered over the bone, and removed, and smoothed over it with encaustic; for indeed a fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	In the treatment of a fracture, first consider the circumstances of the patient; then, if you see from the circumstances that which signifies manifest meaning fear, such as vomiting, cholera, extension, and loss of intellect, and cutting off of voice, and syncopes, and acute fever, and exit of eyes, and redness of them, and similar to these circumstances in many dispositions, undoubtedly it is not cured; and if you see the circumstances are not earthly to you, and you hope for salvation: then begin the treatment of him.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	That is, if a wounded person comes to you, first of all when he is wounded and it is winter, then it is necessary that you strive for the removal of the bone before the sixteenth day according to every arrangement.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if it is in the days of summer, then it is necessary that you hasten to remove the bone before the seventh day, before that which is under the bone from the flesh rots, and those things which we have narrated happen.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	If a fracture of the bone has already reached the membrane touching the brain, and it is with small pieces, and friction: then it is necessary that you cut the broken part, and rubbed, according to what I tell you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	And it is, as you cut the head of the wounded: and cover over the bone according to whatever way possible to you: and according to the shape of the wound, and what is light on the weak.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	If it happens to you when detecting a bone that there is bleeding, or a hot abscess: then oppose it with what is necessary.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And it is, that you fill the place with cloths soaked in wine, and rose oil: and make the wound rest, until it sits pus, and you are secure from the flow of blood.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	Then begin in the treatment of bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	And this is done according to one of two modes.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	There is one way to cut the jaw with a straight and sharp incision knife: and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Then administer another incision wider than the previous incisions, and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	Then administer also another incision wider than the second.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	And the second way is that you have a number of different scalpels, some wider than others, and some shorter than others: and let them be at the last extremity of sharpness, and let them be made of iron or steel: and use ease in striking upon the scalpel so that it does not jar the head, nor injure it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	If however the bone is hard and strong: then it is necessary that you perforate around it before administering the cutting instrument, with boring tools which are called Terebrae not going deeply; and they are not called so unless because they themselves do not pass through the limit of the bone to the flesh beyond it, because the Terebra has a rounded end above that which is under its sharp head, similar to a margin, and a small circle prevents submerging and passing through the thickness of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	And it is fitting for you to take from these terebrae a great number, of which each one should be suitable in quantity and thickness of bone, until you have at hand for the skull a terebrum: whose acute extremity quantity in length and shortness shall be according to the quantity of thickness of that skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	And this is the form of three kinds of terebrae, or trepanes.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	The quality of penetrating in the circumference of a broken bone is: that you place the terebrum over the bone, and turn it with your fingers until you know that the bone has already been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Then move the terebrum to another location, and place it where there is a space between all holes, equal in size to the thickness of the radius, or about that.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	Then cut with a cutting tool where it is between every foramen in the bone: and make it more finely than you can above it from the end of its lightness, as we have said, until you remove the bone, or with your own hand, or with some other of certain instruments which you have prepared for it: such as pincers, and subtle forceps.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	And it is necessary, that you guard with all care, lest the terebrum or scalpel touch anything from the bandage.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	When therefore you go around the bone by perforating it, and having separated it from the sphenoid, if it was continuous with it, and having extracted it, it is necessary that you rasp it, and make the equal extremity of it which remains in the bone with another similar instrument like a cutting knife.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	Nevertheless, it ought to be thin and subtle, more so than other incisions.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	If anything remains of the small bones and splinters, then take them with ease, with that which you have among your instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	Then, after this, care for the wound with the lotions and ointments that we have said.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	And another mode of operation is easy, very far from fear: which Galen said, and praised him with great praise: and this is his word.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	First it is necessary for you to begin to uncover the part of the bone from the place in which the fracture is more severe and more manifest: until when you have uncovered that part, and placed beneath it the extremity of this lenticular Incision, whose this is the form.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	And the lens-shaped part, it does not strike anything soft; and the pointed part of it, biting on two sides of it lengthwise, as you see: so that the lens-shaped part is attached to the hipbone, its face striking the bone with a point.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	Then strike upon the incision with one side of a small hammer until you cut through the whole bone with ease, as it revolves; and be sure from the cloth that no accident will happen in it which you should fear at all.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	And if the surgeon were not a fool among men, and more ignorant of it, nor asleep, then if something remained attached to the bone from the flap in some places, he would cut it off from it with the edge of the lenticular incision tool, and free it from it with ease.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	It is released from it without harm, and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	And if the fracture of a bone does not penetrate to the subcutaneous tissue, and that which is cut off from the bone is its face, and there remain in it roughness and subtle splinters: then it is necessary to shave away that roughness, and to eradicate those splinters with fine razors of which you have prepared a number of various sizes, so that it may be possible for you to administer them in every convenient place, and to make them straighter, according to what the operation leads you to, and the broken bone itself, and its figure.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	And it is necessary that you administer in your work, especially on bones, broader than their rasps.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	Then use something finer after it.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	And do not cease doing this according to continuity, until you arrive at administering finer and more subtle of them all.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	In every wound of whatever kind, and in the case of small capillaries and fine fractures, it is necessary that you give care according to what leads to its repair.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	And there is a matter which is not hidden from everyone who has some study in this art, and it stands upon what we have written and shown in great fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	If however the subcutaneous tissue is detected and retained when you remove the bone; then it is necessary that you take a linen cloth, according to the quantity of the wound, and submerge it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	Then take another piece of cloth, doubled or tripled, and immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it on top of the first cloth; and do this as easily as you can so that it does not irritate the wound.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	Then administer above this broad ligament and do not tighten it unless by the quantity which will hold the wound only: and release it with this care on one day, or two days, until you are certain about the hot abscess.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	Then dissolve it and administer afterwards medicines with which there is superfluous dryness: such as lily roots, and herb flour, and frankincense powder, and aristolochia, and things similar to these: and let it be so that you make from these medicines a powder, which shall be powdered over the wound as they are dry.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	And universally administer in it all medicine of the property of which it is that it cleanses and does not bite.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	And take care according to your ability, so that the wound in your care be clean: and let there not be in it filth of ointment, nor dirtiness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	And do not allow the pus to gather there at all; because when pus gathers over the brain's fat, it spoils it and rots it, and a great evil happens to the sick person afterward; and this sometimes happens in the skull, when it is cleansed from it, especially when care for it is neglected, blackness appears on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	Therefore consider, if accidents happen to the sick which we have said, know that it is undoubtedly harmful.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And if blackness does not occur, except from the medicine which is placed upon it, and it is in the power of that medicine to make that blackness; then it is necessary that you should take one part of honey, three parts of rose oil, and linen with them cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then place him on a couch: afterwards take care of him with appropriate types of healing until he heals.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	On the restoration of the nose when it is broken.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	Know that the two upper parts of the nose are broken only together or one of them; because they are two bones: for the lower part is cartilaginous and it does not break but only attrition, twists, and similar things happen to it.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If one of the two parts is broken, then it is necessary to insert a small finger into the hole of the nose and equal that fracture with your index finger and thumb until the nose returns to its natural form; and let this be done skillfully and easily.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And beware, lest it happen through your operation that pain come upon the weak one.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and the finger cannot reach it, then it is necessary that the extremity of the radius be made equal, in which there is a small thickness.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	If a fracture is in two parts, then make something similar to it, and hasten with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if it is possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then after the seventh, or tenth day at rest of the hot abscess.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Then introduce a linen plug into the end of the Nose, if the fracture is in one part: or introduce two plugs if the fracture is in two parts: and let there be in the plug a thickness such that it fills the opening of the Nose.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And some of the old restorers said that one should pour liniment into butter and change it every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	It does not seem to me, indeed it ought not, that chalk be poured into the albuginea after it has been mixed with mill dust.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then release the ligature until the bone is firm and the cartilage has hardened.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And sometimes a goose feather is introduced into the nose in place of a ligature, after it has been wrapped with a soft cloth: and this holds the fracture of the nose more firmly, so that the patient is not prevented from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	And this thing is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you wish, do it; and if you wish, do differently.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	If it happens that the nose becomes again inflamed while you are operating, apply a plaster to the nose with cauterization, or with a cloth soaked in oil of roses, or a small amount of diacoylon.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	If however a hot abscess does not occur, then it is necessary to apply a poultice made with sesame flour and the powder of frankincense mixed with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	Then place a soft wad on top of it, and do not apply anything at all to the nose.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	If bones of the nose are broken, a small fracture or splintered, then it is necessary that you cut over them and remove them with instruments which are suitable for them.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	Then suture the cut, and take care of it with that which is to be engrafted and consolidated from appropriate plasters or ointments.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	If a wound occurs between the nose, then it is necessary to cure it with lead dressings, and administer a lead tube until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	On the restoration of the lower jaw when it is broken.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	When the lower jaw is broken, and the fracture is not with a wound: then look if the fracture is only on the outside, and it does not break in two, and it bends inwards: then its knowledge is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	Therefore, if there is a fracture in the right part, you must insert your left index finger into the bone of the injured person; similarly, if the fracture is in the left jawbone, then insert the right hand's index finger: and push with it the bump of the fracture inward with ease to the outside with your other hand from the inner part of the bone centrally, and with it equalize it.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	If the fracture of the jawbone has already been separated into two parts, then it is necessary for you to administer traction from the two parts, according to straightness, until it is possible to make them equal.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	If however a shaking or disruption occurs in the teeth: then bind those of which you hope that they will remain with a thread of gold, silver, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then place a pad over the broken jawbone.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Then place over this doubled cloth, and place on top of the cloth a large pad made centrally; or a piece of sole skin equal in length to the jawbone.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then bind the same from above, according to how the bandage is prepared for you, and it is fitting for its application until it is destroyed: and order the sick person to be in tranquility and quiet; and place food of his imbibing gentle.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	If you judge that something is changing in the figure in any way: then hasten and dissolve it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then rectify what has been altered from it, and apply a plaster to it from ground meal powder, with albuginea of egg white, or with sesame flour, after you have removed the cauterization: and place soft wool over the plaster.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	Therefore, as long as that plaster remains attached to it, and the bone's arrangement is not altered, let him be released, so that you do not loosen it, until it heals; or bind the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	Often indeed this fracture is set in three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	If meanwhile a hot abscess occurs, then administer that which we have said many times for its appeasement until the abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if the fracture is with a wound, consider.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	Now the fragment is separated from the bone, or from the saw; then be more subtle in this, that you remove those fragments of the saw with that which is convenient to you in their removal from the instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If, however, the opening of the wound is narrow, then widen it with a lancet according to the amount of necessity you have.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you have removed those rags and nothing remains of them, then close the wound opening, if it is wide; and if not, put over it from plasters that are suitable for it, and they will cover it until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	On the restoration of the collarbone, when it is broken.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	The clavicle is indeed broken most frequently from the front part of the shoulder and its fracture occurs according to one of three modes.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	Or it breaks and is separated into two, besides which things happen to it; and it is easier to restore it.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or thus, which happen in the bone of a shaft: and it is more difficult for restoration.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or so, which is a fracture with a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	And the operation on it when there is a fracture without a wound, is, that you make two assistants present, so that one of them holds the aid which follows the broken Fork, and the other extends the neck towards the part.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then equalize the fracture with your fingers until its form is made, according to what is necessary: and let there be neither prominence nor concavity in it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	If the swelling extends more, then it is necessary to place under the patient's swollen area a sphere from cloth, or wool: and let its size be according to the quantity of your need: and extend and elevate the forceps, and constrict the sphere with your hand, until the fracture is equal, according to what is needed.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If you cannot draw the extremity of the clavicle outwards because it has reached deep within; then, it is necessary to make the patient lie down on his neck and put a pillow medium in size under his shoulder, and have an assistant press the shoulder downwards until the part of the clavicle which is deep rises upwards; and then straighten the fracture and make it even with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If you feel a foreign object from the collarbone, and it moves: then it is necessary to locate it above it and extract that foreign object with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If it is retained in the bone, then use your ingenuity in its incision with one of the Cutters which you have prepared for this purpose, after you have placed under the Forcipes an instrument which saves sifach. And this instrument is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It is like a spoon which has no concavity.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	Let its width be according to that which you need it to be from the size of the bone, and its nature.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	Its length is also according to what is possible for you to the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And let it have two extremities, as you see: and one extremity be wide, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If, however, the wound that you made when extracting a piece of bone is wide, and it is threatened by hot suppuration, then gather the two lips of the wound together with suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if the rupture is small, or a hot abscess threatens: then fill the wound with cloths, and wool according to the quantity of the wound's cut.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	If a hot abscess occurs, then pour linen cloth soaked in rose oil, vinegar, and wine, and place it on top of it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	A stricture of bone when it is without a wound and without a section, is, as you put over the bone a plaster made from flour of mill with albumen of egg.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And place a soft plug upon it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then place a sphere under its point, if you need it so.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Then take a hemamath, that is, a board which the Saracens hold, which is long quite a bit; and let its width be one palm, or thereabouts.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place a small doubled piece over the wool and ointment.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Then take a star from a fine board, whose width is three fingers wide, and similarly in length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then wrap it in a cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then wrap that cloth with a star in the place of the hematoma which falls upon the fracture and its location.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the alheminati upon the fracture as it is revolved, and envelop it upon his neck, and under its sound splint, and under its diseased splint: and reduce it upon every part, and how you see that a stricture holds the fracture a stricture decent: and this is that which is not concealed over thee, and the whole, so that it not be removed as star from above the broken bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	Therefore, it is necessary that you look at the sick person every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Whenever therefore the ligament is softened, and you see the star already removed: then rectify it, and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place the patient's sleep upon his back, and place under his pillow at his sleep a small cushion at night, so that when he is raised it will help him from the side of himself.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	Therefore, the fracture of the clavicle is elevated by elevating the shoulder.
