¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	On speech in dislocation.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXIV.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	A dislocation is an exit of some joint from its place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Therefore, it is prohibited from its movement, and its member's figure is defiled.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And he causes pain and grievous wounds to happen upon the sick person.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	When therefore dislocation happens to anyone, then it is necessary to hasten to its restoration: and do not delay it at all.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	If this is delayed, the place becomes a boil, and perhaps with it a reduction of the dislocation.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Therefore, it should not be moved or extended at the hour of its suppuration.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	For it often causes spasms and painful aches.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when this happens, then it is necessary that you hasten to the phlebotomy of the sick man.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then let it be left alone until the abscess rests.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then the limb will be cauterized with hot water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then it is to be returned with ease.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And he will cure every limb with it whose remembrance comes to its place.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I have indeed arranged the chapters on dislocations, also according to what preceded in fractures, from the upper part of the body down to the lower.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	On the treatment of a dislocation of the lower jawbone.
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	The two mandibles are rarely dislocated.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And dislocation of both occurs according to one of two modes.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Or if they are removed from their places by little removal and softened for a short time.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are dislocated by dislocation, intact, complete, until they soften to the part of the chest, until pus runs from the wound of the patient, and he cannot hold it, nor can he close his mouth, and his tongue is involved with speech.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	When its dislocation is small, then it returns to several dispositions by itself with little.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	If it is a complete dislocation, then it must be reduced quickly and not delayed at all:  and let the attendant hold the head of the sick person, and let the physician insert his thumb into the root of the mandible dislocation between its bone, if the dislocation is on one side.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or he may insert two fingers at once, if the dislocation is from two parts.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And the remaining fingers of his hand be outside, with which he makes even.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And command the sick person to clean his jawbone and make it whole for eating on every side.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the physician straightens the Jawbone and pushes the Jawbone until it returns to its place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If the reduction is difficult, especially if both mandibles are involved at the same time, then administer vapor with hot water and oil until easy reduction of both occurs. Do not delay the reduction of both altogether, as we have said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When therefore they return and are made equal, and the bone of the infirm is closed, and they are not softened: then place upon them little wads of cloth, with a cerate which is made from wax: and rose oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then it is bound with ease with soft ligatures.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	Let the patient's sleep be upon his back; and let his head be standing between two cushions, so that he does not move it to the right or left; nor attempt, or be forced, to chew anything; rather, let his food be a gentle broth, until when the pains are removed, and the jaw is knit; then let him eat what he wants, and administer it with ease.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	He should not labor over the operation of his mouth at eating and drinking, and speaking, until the jaw has been set and healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If the reduction of the two jaws is difficult when they are dislocated at some time and do not return to their places, then many times fevers and constant thirst occur from this, and perhaps the belly of the sick person is loosened, and perhaps he vomits pure bile.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When therefore you see that: then you will know, that it is destruction, and many times he who happens to have it dies within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	On the reduction of dislocation of the collarbone and shoulder.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The furcula is not dislocated from within because of its continuity with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And sometimes it is dislocated outwards: and this is made known to the sense.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And its restoration is, that he lie down the sick on his back, and stretch out his arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then grasp the place with the palm of your hand firmly, for it will return.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then place upon the very same plaster, and pads, and bind it.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	The extremities which follow the elbow and continue with it, are not dislocated, except rarely.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	If it becomes dislocated on some day, then it is necessary that it be reduced and set equal as we have said, and which was prepared for you.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then place over the same dressing and lint, and constriction.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And command the sick person to adhere to tranquility and quiet until he is healed.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And with this same cure the limb of the shoulder is reduced when it is also separated from its place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	On the Reduction of a Dislocation of the Shoulder.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	Know that the humerus is not dislocated except in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	Of which one is, that it be dislocated to the part of the little toe downwards.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second is, that it be dislocated to the side of the breast.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it is dislocated to the upper part of the humerus: and that happens rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And it is not displaced posteriorly because of the spatula.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it is not dislocated anteriorly, because of the nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	And most frequently it is displaced and goes out toward the lower part towards the groin: especially in those whose flesh is little.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	Because it comes out quickly, and goes in quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	In those with a lot of flesh, the opposite is true, namely that it comes out with difficulty and goes in with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happens to some men by a blow or a fall, and the humerus becomes inflamed with a hot abscess, and this is thought to be because it is already dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	Therefore, you ought to experiment with it until you stand upon the certainty of it, and then proceed in its cure.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And it is known that dislocation occurs when there is a turning downwards of the nipple; and distinguish between a dislocated shoulder, and a healthy shoulder.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	And you find among them a manifest diversity, and you find in the head of the Humerus a concavity, and under the touch at the head of the humerus as if it were an egg: and the weak one cannot reduce the hand to his ear, nor move it in all movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And similarly, if it is dislocated towards the chest, or upwards: then you find a manifest touch, and it is not hidden.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And this dislocation is easily reduced when it is recent, or when the child is weak.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And its reduction is that he raises his hand up.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then place your thumbs under his little finger and raise the joint with strength upwards to its place; and let the assistant raise his hand and extend it upwards.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then he places it lower, for he himself returns quickly.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	If it does not return through what we have said, and many days have passed since the dislocation occurred at first: then it is necessary for the sick person to bathe in hot water, and an embrocation which softens and soothes be administered, such as if roots of marshmallow, fennel, and melilot are boiled in water, and it be given.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the patient is laid flat on his back: and under his armpit a sphere of wool is placed, which is equal between softness and tightness.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the physician places his heel upon a sphere, and elevates the shoulder with strength, and draws the hand of the infirm to the lower parts.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another attendant shall hold the head of the sick person so that it is not moved downwards: for it indeed returns immediately.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you wish, reduce him according to this method: and it is that you make present a man who is longer than the weak one, and stands on his side, and inserts his shoulder under the weakened one's armpit: and he elevates the armpit of his upwards until the weak one is suspended in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another assistant shall draw the hand of the infirm to the lower part of his belly.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	If the patient is weak: then it is necessary that something else be suspended with him so that he may weigh down; for the dislocation returns immediately.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And it is reduced also according to another manner: and is, as a long piece of wood is laid on the ground, whose head is round in figure: like a death shroud's sleeve: that it not be thick, nor thin.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then a soft cloth is placed under the patient after linen has been placed over his head; and the patient shall stand upright according to the length of the wood.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then his hand is extended toward the lower part on the other side, and his body is extended from the other side with strength; for the joint returns to its place with speed.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	If its reduction through all that we have said proves difficult, then use this treatment: take a piece of wood whose length is the quantity of two arms, and whose width is the quantity of four fingers, and whose thickness is the quantity of two fingers: which should have a rounded head, so that it may ease the entry of its depth into the pudendum, according to this form.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then soft cloths are tied over the round head so that it does not injure the weak wood.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then a plank is placed under the sick person's hand so that it can be extended, or the arm above the wood up to the lower part, and the wood is bound over the helper and the arm and extremity of the hand.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then the arm is placed upon the step of the ladder lengthwise, and the hand is extended downward, and the rest of the body is let down suspended from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	The suture enters at once.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	When therefore the entrance is completed according to whichever way is possible: then it is necessary that you place under the linen sphere of equal quantity from wool.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then place a prepared plaster made from ground powder with frankincense and egg white over the entire shoulder, as it turns over above.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then tighten the suture under a proper bandage: and the ligature is rolled over the plaster from above: and his hand is tied to his neck, and let it be laid down, and let not the hand be moved for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And it is necessary that little food be given to the sick person until the limb is strengthened; because it is swifter to its healing.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then a larger one should be placed after seven days, or five, and it is removed with movement.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If therefore it is set and does not soften, then now it is healed.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	If a joint is dislocated many times because of moisture that occurs to it, or because of another cause: then it is necessary that a cautery with three holes be administered to it, according to what was said before in the chapter on cauterization.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	If all of this is done and after seven days the ligament is loosened and the joint does not hold together, and the plaster is reapplied and tightened over it several times, and it does not firm up, and falls off, and it is not possible to raise it upward: then know that the nerves which are to the shoulder head have already been cut or stretched or softened: and know that the joint will never set in its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	Reduction of a dislocation which occurs towards the chest and nipple, or to the rear, is carried out with impulse and extension with the hands until it returns, and then the rest of the constriction and care are administered until it heals.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If after healing heaviness occurs in the limb and slowness of its movement, then let the sick person use a bath many times, until that heaviness is lessened and it returns to its original nature.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	On the treatment of elbow dislocation.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	Know that the joint of the elbow is dislocated with difficulty, and similarly it returns with difficulty; and indeed it is dislocated to all parts, and especially to the anterior, or to the posterior.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	And its dislocation is not hidden from you: because it is falling under sight, and under touch, according to whatever form it is dislocated.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you join the dislocated thigh with the healthy one, it will be made manifest to you.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	The joint is concave, and it cannot bend the arm, nor touch its own shoulder with it.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you hurry and reduce the dislocation immediately, before a hot abscess happens to it.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if it happens that he has a hot abscess, its reduction is difficult; and perhaps it does not heal at all, especially when it is towards the rear.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	It is indeed worse than all kinds of dislocations, and causes more violent pain; and many times death descends with it.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the restoration of it when it is one of those things which is possible to reduce, is, that the hand be extended with two hands: and the arm be expanded, and the hands of the physician be upon the upper arm and beneath it, and he himself push the joint with his thumbs or with the root of his palm until it returns to its place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Or if the dislocation is to the front: then it returns so that it doubles its hand with its own hand until it strikes with the root of its palm the elbow which is dislocated.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	If the dislocation does not yield to reduction, then administer a violent, strong extension; and let two men extend the arm, and let two others also hold it, so that it is not moved during extension.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then the arm is turned to every part after it has been wrapped above its hand with a doubled length of cloth, or a wide bandage.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	And when the physician touches a joint with his hand, he should anoint it with oil so that it may be one of those which help in the lubrication of the joint with ease.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then drive the joint with a vehement impulse until it returns.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after reduction it is necessary that a plaster be placed upon it, which has astringency and drying power with the membrane of an egg; and the bandage should be tightened moderately.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And the arm shall be suspended from the neck of the infirm: and let it be released for several days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then it should be loosened.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If therefore the joint is set in its place, then untie the ligament from it, and release it.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you see the joint not closing well, then apply a fresh dressing and bandage again, and leave it for several days until it closes.
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then dissolve it.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	If however it happens to him heaviness after the reduction of the joint, and the arrangement is in motion: then administer moistening in bathing, and subtle friction, and compression, until it is lined up, or place on top of the hip joint, that is, a thick lamb's wool.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then it is ligated, and let it be left upon it day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then take it out, and introduce it into the bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	When therefore he sweats, then rub the joint with friction tempered.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then it is repeated over the same area with a single, second, and third wipe with a washcloth, until softened.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	And if you wish, place over the same manure, moist, heated with butter, and bind over it.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Do this several times.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	For indeed it is softened and returns to its proper state.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	On the treatment of a dislocated shoulder, Al-Zahrawi.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	The joint of the hand is often dislocated, that is, the joint between the arm and hand.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And the reduction of its dislocation is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	Contrary to other joints.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that speed be in the reduction of a dislocation in the hour in which it occurs, before the place is suppurated: or a hot suppuration will happen in it.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of a dislocation is that you place the hand of the infirm person upon the board, and let the assistant extend her hand; and the physician places his palm upon the prominence of the joint, and drives it until it returns.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	Nevertheless, it ought to be considered, if the palm has already retreated to the stomach of the hand: then let the infirm person place the back of his hand upon a table at extension and reduction: and if the dislocation is proceeding to the back of the hand, then let the position of his hand be intrinsically above the table, that is, the inner part of his hand above the table, so that the hand of the physician may fall upon that eminence of the joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If therefore it returns immediately, it is good: and if not, then bind it with a soothing plaster for an abscess: and dismiss him, and do not repeat it.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	If he does not tolerate it, and you cannot bring about its reduction after days have passed, yet the joint remains according to its crookedness; and it does not harm the sick person, except that it softens the hand, and is unable to grasp anything: then know that the nerves have been severed or rubbed.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	There is therefore no intelligence in it, unless it be tightened with a cautery near its case.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps that thing doesn't matter.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	When therefore Almahassem does not return, then place upon him the plaster which we have recounted.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then it is bound and left for five days; afterward it is loosened and left, and the hand is exercised.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	If movement is prevented and something heavy happens to it, then soften it with warm water and friction several times until it softens.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	On the treatment of finger dislocations.
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When a finger is dislocated from its place, whether it be to any part, or from its place in the palm of the hand, to its back, or to its belly: then extend the finger, and push the dislocation with your thumbs until it returns.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the head of the finger, and suspend it towards the part toward which it is dislocated, and let it be for two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then suspend him, and extend him, until he is equal to straight on that day of his.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When therefore night shall have come, bind it according to its own story: and do not cease to loosen it in the day: and exercise him with motion: and bind it at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Do this for several days until it tightens.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	And similarly do with it if it is dislocated to the belly of the hand: and bind it to that part, and make with it your first operation, until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	And similarly do when it is dislocated to the other parts.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	On the cure of a dislocation of the vertebrae of the back.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter XXXI.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When it happens to someone that their spinal column in the back or neck is completely dislocated, or many vertebrae are removed from their places: then there is no cure for it, because death rushes upon the sick person.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And the sign of it is that the stool of the sick person comes out without will, and he cannot hold it: and many times some limbs of him are softened, or two legs of him, or two arms of him, or one of them: or a single hip bone is removed from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	For it is often removed, which is often removed to four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	Therefore, that which is moved to the rear, is called Gibbosity.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	Now as for its cure, consider this, if hunchback occurs from childhood, then there is no cure in it, nor is there any healing whatsoever from it.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	In that which happens by chance, or percussion, or similar things, the ancients have already said ways of healing in verbose speech.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Of which very much does not return with profit.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I myself have abbreviated from that, which little excuses me because of its nearness to my intent; and in my exposition which I have exposed it, and fashioned its instrument in a different way than they showed it, and exposed it.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	Therefore I say that in a hunchback which occurs from the front part, there is no skill nor healing from it.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And similarly in that which is done on both sides also.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And it is not cured from these, unless that which happens on the back properly, as I tell you: and it is, that the sick person be stretched out over his face over a level platform near the wall: and there should be spread under him a wet cloth, so that his chest is not harmed.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then a straight fixed piece of wood is placed in the hole in the ground at the foot's end, about the head of it: and another piece of wood about its feet at the other end of the foot: and let the servant hold the wood, and not be fastened in the hole.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And one assistant shall hold another.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then wrap over the head of the sick person, and under the tie of his ligament soft and firm: and extend the extremity of the ligament to the wood which is at its head: and bind it there.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	Then tighten another ligament above its bends, and above its knees, and at its groin.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then gather all the ligaments and tie them to a second stick that is at his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then let every assistant extend to the part of the stick a ligament, and do not remove two ligaments from their places where they are fixed; but however, let them not be fastened, as we have said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the physician places his palms upon the spine with strength until it returns, or places a board upon it.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then he ties his feet to the board until he returns.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	If it does not return through this treatment, then take a board whose length is about three spans.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And the hollow in the wall of which we said that it is near the sick person, place in which the end of the board may enter.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle board over the Spondilem.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And the physician shall place his feet upon the other extremity.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And he will pull tight well until the vertebra be contracted, and return to its place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	Then if you wish, operate with a lathe that is wrapped with your hand: and it is, as to fasten in the ground at the head of the sick man in the last foot two logs, whose length is the length of one arm: and at his head in the last foot two logs.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	Let the length between any piece of wood be one palm; and now a hole has been made everywhere, through which the drill runs: and let the whole wood be firmly set in the ground so that it moves not at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And a round piece of wood is introduced: and it is a  turning tool in which the ligament is rotated in the two holes of two pieces of wood.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at the end of it is an opening, into which a piece of wood is fixed, whose length is a palm with that which revolves; and in two other pieces of wood there is similarly that one.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	Then tighten the ligaments which you tightened in the chest of the sick person with a rope which is near his head: and the ligaments which you tightened in his legs with a rope which is near his feet.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	Then let there be at every lathe a servant who will turn his hand with a linen cloth, with which the lathe is turned; and the physician shall level the Spondyle, according to what we have said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of the forceps that follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then after the sponge is returned and the place is leveled, it is necessary to place a dry dressing with egg white.
Deinde stuppam.	Then a plug.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Afterwards, place above the plaster a star from wood, whose width is three fingers, or about so many.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And its length is the quantity that it takes up in the place of hunchbackness, and over the part of the healthy vertebra.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then it is bound with the ligament which we have said.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And let the sick person use fine nourishment until he is healed.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	If something remains prominent at the end of healing: then it is necessary that softening and soothing medicines be administered, along with the application of the board which we narrated a long time ago.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And now a lead plate is administered in it.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And sometimes there occurs a prominence in the last vertebra of the back; and it is thought to be through this dislocation, and it is that bone which now protrudes.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore it is not necessary that a presumption be made with this medicine; for perhaps it will cause death.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	On the treatment of a dislocated shoulder.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter XXXII.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	Know this, that the joints of the Ancha, and the joints of the shoulder, do not occur, unless dislocation only; and it does not happen to them what happens to other joints from slight removal, and concavity.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And indeed the articulation of the ankle is dislocated in four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	That is because it is displaced anteriorly and posteriorly.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	And it is moved most certainly inwards; and little outwards, and backwards.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	And the cure of its dislocation inwards is: because when you join the broken leg to the sound one, it is longer: and its knee is more prominent than that of a healthy one, and the broken leg cannot bend at the groin: and there is a place following the groin that is an abscess with hot pus, because the hip head has already reached there.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	And the sign of him who has a dislocation outwards is that those things which are on the outside are contrary to those things which are inside.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	And the sign of one who has a dislocation forward is, because he stretches his healthy leg according to its proportion; however, he does not double it without pain which is in the knee: and if he attempts to walk, he cannot pass over it forward: and his urine is retained, and his groin suppurates, and when walking his foot falls upon his heel.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	And the sign of him to whom this dislocation happens is that he does not straighten his knee, nor can he bend it before he bends his groin: and his leg is also shorter than the other: and his groin is softened, and the head of the hip is at the place of the ilium.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	The reduction of this dislocation is, as you consider, if the dislocation is old, which already grows stale with having it.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then if you administer its reduction, and it remains according to its disposition: then there is no treatment at all in it.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	Therefore it is not necessary that full presumption be made of him.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	In that one, however, whose dislocation is recent, and is of one of the four kinds of dislocation: then hasten to this, so that you may wish the joint, and extend it both inwards and outwards, and move it with your right and left hand: for perhaps it will return, and does not need other care.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	If this method does not work, then it is necessary that you prepare a strong assistant, and he should extend the leg of the patient from its lower part: either with his hands, or with a bandage which is tied above the knee; and another assistant should extend the hand of the patient from above, so that he may insert his hands under the testicles.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then he will tighten with a soft bandage on the root of the hip and hold the other end of the bandage.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And let its extension be either from the anterior part of the groin to the point of the collarbone, or from the posterior to the part of the back.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And let their extension all be as one, until the sick person is lifted with his body from the ground, and remains hanging.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	And this kind of extension is a common kind of the four kinds.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	If therefore the dislocation returns with that which we said, it is good: and if not, then it is necessary to do all kinds of that which I will say concerning the cure proper.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	When indeed a dislocation is toward the interior, it ought that the sick person be laid on his healthy side in the reduction.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then he places a ligature above the root of the hip, where it is between the head of the hip and the place which is under the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then extend the ligament upward from the groin area to the higher part of the body, to the collarbone.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then let another attendant take strong arms and reduce the large place of the weak hip, and extend it outward with violent extension.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	For now he returns to his place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	And this kind is easier of healing than the rest, in which this limb is reduced.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	If he excuses himself from you and does not obey you for the entry with this kind of treatment at all: then it is necessary that two feet of the infirm be bound together simultaneously with a strong, soft bandage, above the two heels, and above the two knees; and let the length of each be four finger widths from its counterpart; and let the infirm leg be extended more than the other by two finger widths.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then let the sick person be suspended over the head of a piece of wood that is in the house: and let its length from the ground be the quantity of two arms.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then command the strong young man to brace the hip joint; and let another support him who is injured; and let another youth brace the hip with strength, for the joint returns to its place with speed.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	In its reduction, however, when it is a dislocation to the outside, it is necessary that the sick person lie on a platform, according to what we have narrated in him who has a hunchback.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And a bandage be tied over the leg of him, the infirm one, and over his chest.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then two boards are placed, one at his feet, and the other at his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then a piece of wood added in the middle of the foot should be placed, well fixed: upon which wet cloths should be wrapped so that it does not harm the sick person: and let the wood be between his hips, so that it is not pulled down towards the lower parts when extending.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then let every assistant extend his part, and the physician equalize the reduction with his hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If therefore he obeys restoration, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place upon that same table, and press it down, as we said in the hunchback, equally.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that the sick person lie on his healthy side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	And when the dislocation is to the front, then it is necessary that the leg of the injured person be extended quickly; and this is according to this same account upon a footstool: and the physician places the palm of his right hand above the groin of the injured person.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he constricts it with the other hand, and with that constriction, he places it extended below to the part of the knee.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	And if the dislocation is to the rear: then it is not necessary for the infirm to be extended downwards and raised above the ground: rather, it is necessary that he be placed upon a hard thing, as it is necessary, as we said, if an inch of his is dislocated outwards, according to what we said about his lying on two boards: and it is above his face, and ligaments are extended: according to what we said recently.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	And it is necessary that a compression be administered with a board also over the place to which the joint goes out, when the reduction is completed as it ought.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of its return is not hidden from you: and it is, that you extend the two legs of the weak one: and when you see them equal, and the weak one tightens his leg, and expands it without excuse: then know, that now the limb returns, according to what is necessary: then join the two hips, and put a plaster, and tighten with an imemati, that is, a wheel: so that it not move any part: and adhere the weak one in quiet for three days, or four.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then solve the ligament, and the dressing, and compare the leg with the other: then if you see them equal in state, then know that the dislocation is already fixed: therefore discharge the sick person to walk.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you see anything softening: then return, and plaster it, and bind it according to your first stricture: and let it stand for even three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then resolve it and make it slow down in walking on both sides for several days, until it is well strengthened.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	On the dislocation of the knee.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	The knee is dislocated in three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	It is dislocated externally, internally, and downwards, namely backwards.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	And it is not dislocated forward.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	And the sign of its dislocation is that you bid the infirm person apply his leg to his hip.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	If it does not adhere with the hip, then you know that the knee is dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	And the restoration of all kinds of dislocation of it is that you make the weak person sit straight so that he can now extend his leg if he can, and stick your back to his face: and place his foot between your feet.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then make his knee adhere with your palms, and straighten them between your fingers upon his knee.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Then apply with your palm both sides of his knee with fortitude.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	And another assistant shall extend his foot until the knee returns to its place.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	And the sign of its return is that the leg adheres to the hip with ease, not laboriousness.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then apply a plaster and adhere the leg to the hip.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then bind that together with three or four strips of linen.
Deinde solue ea.	Then loosen it.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	And let not the sick person walk for several days until he is healed.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	If, however, reduction is refused to you, then administer a strong extension with ligaments, of which the preceding narrative in the treatment of the ankle has been related, until it returns.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	On the treatment of a calcaneus dislocation.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	Sometimes the calcaneus is removed with a small incision, and sometimes it is dislocated according to its joint.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	And its dislocation occurs, either inward or outward.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	And the sign of its dislocation is that you see the calcaneus inflated, proceeding to the part to which it dislocates.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	The cure of its removal is easy and consists in stretching it gently with the hands and leveling it until it returns.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	In the treatment of this condition when it is dislocated according to the completion, it is necessary that you make the sick person sit straight: and let him be held by a strong servant very firmly from the posterior part of his back, in the middle of it.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then hold you with your right hand his foot from its upper part, and with your left hand from the lower part of his foot in place of the heel.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then draw the foot toward you with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	Then with two left incisions.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then extend with the left and push the chest of the foot with the right towards the leg without effort.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do that twice, as we have narrated.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then drive the breast of the foot toward the leg in the third space, and you draw the tendon.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	If therefore it returns in one, or in two, according to this mode, and you see the foot even, it is good: and if not, then repeat the operation on it; because it itself returns.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	If it is forbidden to you to reduce it with what we have told you: then make the sick person lie on his back on the ground, and place a small pillow firmly on the ground, so that it falls between his hips: and you have already wrapped him in cloth, so that he does not harm the sick person.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then let the assistant take hold of his hip: afterwards let another assistant stretch out his foot, either with his hands or with a bandage which is tied above the ankle.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then let every assistant extend against the extension of his own comparison: and a pillow shall stand between the two hips of the infirm retaining him, so that his body is not pulled down during the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then the physician reduces the dislocation with his hands, and another assistant holds the healthy leg down toward the lower part.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For dislocation returns with speed.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	When therefore a dislocation returns, and health of its return is declared to you: then place a plaster and padding, and bind it firmly with ligaments, and tie the foot with a ligament to the leg.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	And it is necessary that you be careful or fearful of the nerves which are above the heel bone, so that the ligament above them may not be too strong and injure them.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then let him be dismissed after two days, or three.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	If the ligament is softened, tighten it; then loosen it on the third or fourth day, and forbid the sick person from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	If he nevertheless attempts to walk before that time, there is no safety unless the dislocation dissolves over him, and it is corrupted, and does not receive after that cure.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	If it happens that he has a hot abscess, then it is necessary to administer that which we previously narrated elsewhere concerning the treatment of this, and an ointment, until it is removed.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	On the dislocation of the toes of the foot, and its treatment.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXXV.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	It is necessary that what is dislocated be equal with it by extension little without labor; and indeed this is not difficult, but rather is easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	If the dislocation is in certain joints of the foot's back: then it is necessary that he who is infirm make his foot sit upon an equal place to the earth, or upon a board: and stand thus as if walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then you stand, and put your foot upon that which projects from those joints.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then press it with your foot with strength until it returns and you see it level, and there is no prominence in the place.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then place under his foot a board which will catch the whole foot, which has two heads.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	Then tighten it with a bandage for three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then loosen it and have him rest from walking for many days, until it becomes tight and secure from the reduction.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	On the kinds of dislocations with wound or fracture.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter XXXVI.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When something happens from this, and you attempt its cure and restoration, many times death follows: and for that reason it is not fitting that one should presume to undertake the cure of this kind, unless he is prudent in the art, long-experienced, merciful, pious, slow, not bold, nor presumptuous; and that he may use in the inception medicines which pacify hot abscesses only; and dismiss the sick by divine judgment.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Unless you see or hope for health from death with gentleness of sickness and in which something appears hopeful.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Therefore, attempt to reduce it immediately at the beginning of the matter, before a hot abscess occurs.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	If therefore the limb returns, according to what we wish, then administer a regimen that soothes the abscess; and care for the wound with that which is fitting for it from drying ointments.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	If the dislocation is with a fracture, and there are fragments of bone separated, then try to remove them, and do what we said in simple ailments from that which preceded concerning their locations.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	And beware according to your strength, and guard yourself from entering the way of fear: according to what my proclamation has preceded you.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For that is better for you before your Creator, and more enduring for your glory, and more healthful for your body among those who are with you in your time.
